   155‚Üí- Nicolas absorbs the loss (risk premium in 70% split)
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí### Speed Bonuses (Optional - Phase 3)
   158‚Üí
   159‚Üí**If mission delivered in <50% estimated time:**
   160‚Üí- Team commission **+10%** bonus
   161‚Üí- Example: $600 mission, 7 days estimated, delivered in 3 days
   162‚Üí  - Kara: $90 + $9 = $99
   163‚Üí  - Reanance: $54 + $5.40 = $59.40
   164‚Üí  - Bigbosexf: $36 + $3.60 = $39.60
   165‚Üí
   166‚Üí**Not implemented yet** - waiting for team to prove baseline performance first.
   167‚Üí
   168‚Üí---
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí## Transparency & Tracking
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí### What Team Sees
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí**After each mission completion:**
   175‚Üí```
   176‚Üíüìä Mission #47 Payment Breakdown
   177‚Üí
   178‚ÜíMission: OpenAI chatbot integration
   179‚ÜíClient paid: $600
   180‚ÜíDate: 2025-11-05
   181‚ÜíSOL price at payment: $180
   182‚Üí
   183‚ÜíYOUR EARNINGS:
   184‚Üí‚úÖ Kara: $90 (15%) = 0.5 SOL
   185‚Üí‚úÖ Reanance: $54 (9%) = 0.3 SOL
   186‚Üí‚úÖ Bigbosexf: $36 (6%) = 0.2 SOL
   187‚Üí
   188‚ÜíBREAKDOWN:
   189‚Üí- Team total: $180 (30%)
   190‚Üí- Nicolas: $420 (70%)
   191‚Üí  - Upwork fee: -$60
   192‚Üí  - AI costs: -$48
   193‚Üí  - Net: $312
   194‚Üí
   195‚ÜíPAYMENT SENT:
   196‚Üí‚úÖ 0.5 SOL (~$90) ‚Üí Kara's wallet (7xK9...)
   197‚Üí‚úÖ 0.3 SOL (~$54) ‚Üí Reanance's wallet (9mP3...)
   198‚Üí‚úÖ 0.2 SOL (~$36) ‚Üí Bigbosexf's wallet (2hR7...)
   199‚Üí
   200‚ÜíTransaction IDs: [Solscan links]
   201‚Üí
   202‚ÜíYou can hold SOL, convert to USDC, or cash out to NGN via Binance.
   203‚Üí```
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí### Monthly Summary
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí**Sent to team on 1st of month:**
   208‚Üí```
   209‚Üíüìà October 2025 Summary
   210‚Üí
   211‚ÜíTotal missions: 12
   212‚ÜíTotal revenue: $7200
   213‚Üí
   214‚ÜíYOUR EARNINGS:
   215‚ÜíKara: $1080 (from 12 missions)
   216‚ÜíReanance: $648
   217‚ÜíBigbosexf: $432
   218‚Üí
   219‚ÜíAverage per mission:
   220‚ÜíKara: $90
   221‚ÜíReanance: $54
   222‚ÜíBigbosexf: $36
   223‚Üí
   224‚ÜíTop mission: #52 ($1200 - AI automation)
   225‚ÜíFastest delivery: #47 (3 days)
   226‚Üí```
   227‚Üí
   228‚Üí---
   229‚Üí
   230‚Üí## Why This Structure Works
   231‚Üí
   232‚Üí### For Team
   233‚Üí
   234‚Üí**1. Competitive rates (3-10x local market)**
   235‚Üí- Nigeria median dev salary: ~$300-500/month
   236‚Üí- Kara earning: $900-3000/month (3-10x)
   237‚Üí- Reanance/Bigbosexf: 2-6x local rates
   238‚Üí
   239‚Üí**2. Purchasing Power Parity advantage**
   240‚Üí- $900/month in Nigeria = $4500-9000/month lifestyle (doctor/engineer salary)
   241‚Üí- $600/month in C√¥te d'Ivoire = $3000-6000/month lifestyle
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí**3. Performance incentives**
   244‚Üí- Speed ‚Üí higher effective $/hr
   245‚Üí- Quality ‚Üí more missions/month
   246‚Üí- Higher-value missions ‚Üí higher absolute earnings
   247‚Üí
   248‚Üí**4. Zero overhead**
   249‚Üí- No time tracking
   250‚Üí- No timesheets
   251‚Üí- No employment paperwork
   252‚Üí- Just ship missions, get paid
   253‚Üí
   254‚Üí### For Nicolas
   255‚Üí
   256‚Üí**1. Fair risk premium (70%)**
   257‚Üí- Fronts all capital (1-3 weeks before Upwork pays)
   258‚Üí- Absorbs all failures (client doesn't pay = Nicolas loss, team protected)
   259‚Üí- Built entire Mind Protocol infrastructure (years of R&D)
   260‚Üí- Covers all platform costs (AI, Upwork, Claude Code)
   261‚Üí- Lives in expensive market (Lyon vs Lagos)
   262‚Üí
   263‚Üí**2. Scalable margins**
   264‚Üí- Higher prices ‚Üí better margins (team % stays same, absolute $ increases)
   265‚Üí- More missions ‚Üí economies of scale
   266‚Üí- Team gets more efficient ‚Üí higher $/hr for everyone
   267‚Üí
   268‚Üí**3. Simple operations**
   269‚Üí- No payroll
   270‚Üí- No employment law
   271‚Üí- No benefits/taxes
   272‚Üí- Just revenue splits
   273‚Üí
   274‚Üí---
   275‚Üí
   276‚Üí## Purchasing Power Context
   277‚Üí
   278‚Üí**Why team earns "less" nominally but wins massively:**
   279‚Üí
   280‚Üí| Item | France (Nicolas) | Nigeria (Team) | Ratio |
   281‚Üí|------|------------------|----------------|-------|
   282‚Üí| Rent (1br apt) | ‚Ç¨800/month | ‚Ç¶80k (~$50) | **16x cheaper** |
   283‚Üí| Meal at restaurant | ‚Ç¨15 | ‚Ç¶2k (~$1.30) | **11x cheaper** |
   284‚Üí| Internet (fiber) | ‚Ç¨30/month | ‚Ç¶10k (~$6.50) | **4.6x cheaper** |
   285‚Üí| Transportation | ‚Ç¨60/month | ‚Ç¶15k (~$10) | **6x cheaper** |
   286‚Üí| **Total cost of living** | **‚Ç¨1500+/month** | **‚Ç¶200k (~$130)/month** | **11x cheaper** |
   287‚Üí
   288‚Üí**So when Kara earns $900/month:**
   289‚Üí- Nicolas needs ~‚Ç¨1500 ($1640) just to survive in Lyon
   290‚Üí- Kara needs ~‚Ç¶200k ($130) to survive in Lagos
   291‚Üí- **Kara's $900 = ~6.9 months of living expenses**
   292‚Üí- **Nicolas's $2520 = ~1.5 months of living expenses**
   293‚Üí
   294‚ÜíThis is why 70/30 split is fair despite nominal dollar differences.
   295‚Üí
   296‚Üí---
   297‚Üí
   298‚Üí## Future Adjustments
   299‚Üí
   300‚Üí### When to increase team %:
   301‚Üí
   302‚Üí**Scenario A: Revenue >$20k/month consistently (3+ months)**
   303‚Üí- Consider increasing team % to 35% (split: 17%/11%/7%)
   304‚Üí- Nicolas still maintains healthy margin at 65%
   305‚Üí
   306‚Üí**Scenario B: Team takes on more responsibility**
   307‚Üí- If team starts handling client calls ‚Üí Reanance +2%
   308‚Üí- If team starts finding clients ‚Üí Bigbosexf +2%
   309‚Üí- If team starts architecting solutions ‚Üí Kara +2%
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí**Scenario C: After 6+ months proven performance**
   312‚Üí- Add base salary component ($200-400/month) + lower commission
   313‚Üí- Provides stability while maintaining performance incentives
   314‚Üí
   315‚Üí---
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí## Payment Structure Summary
   318‚Üí
   319‚Üí**Current (Phase 2 - First 3-6 months):**
   320‚Üí- Pure commission: 70% Nicolas / 15% Kara / 9% Reanance / 6% Bigbosexf
   321‚Üí- Payment via Solana (SOL) - instant, near-zero fees
   322‚Üí- Pay when Nicolas receives Upwork funds
   323‚Üí
   324‚Üí**Future (Phase 3 - After proven track record):**
   325‚Üí- Consider base salary + commission hybrid
   326‚Üí- Consider speed bonuses (+10% for <50% time)
   327‚Üí- Consider referral bonuses (10% of first mission)
   328‚Üí
   329‚Üí**Target state (Phase 4 - Scaled agency):**
   330‚Üí- 15-20 missions/month
   331‚Üí- Team earning $1500-3000/month each
   332‚Üí- Nicolas net $5000-8000/month
   333‚Üí- Predictable, sustainable, scalable
   334‚Üí
   335‚Üí---
   336‚Üí
   337‚Üí**Questions or adjustments needed? Update this doc and notify team via Telegram.**
   338‚Üí
   339‚Üí---
   340‚Üí
   341‚Üí## Related Documents

messages.content: Now I'll update the payment structure to clearly separate Nicolas's GROSS (70%) from NET (after operational costs).

input.old_string:
## Commission Structure

**Total revenue split per mission:**

| Role | % | Reasoning |
|------|---|-----------|
| **Nicolas** | **70%** | Mind Protocol infrastructure, all financial/quality risk, capital (fronts 1-3 weeks), platform costs (AI, Upwork fees), expensive market (Lyon) |
| **Kara (Developer)** | **15%** | Implementation, testing, deployment - highest time investment (~10h/mission) |
| **Reanance (Specifier + Client)** | **9%** | Client-facing, ongoing relationship, spec quality, change control - critical for repeat business (~2.5h + ongoing) |
| **Bigbosexf (Hunter + QA)** | **6%** | Lead finding, proposal sending, QA testing - important but bounded time (~4.5h/mission) |

**Total team:** 30%
**Total Nicolas:** 70% (minus AI costs ~5-8%, minus Upwork fees ~10% = **52-55% net**)

## Commission Structure

**Total revenue split per mission:**

| Role | % | Reasoning |
|------|---|-----------|
| **Nicolas (GROSS)** | **70%** | Mind Protocol infrastructure, all financial/quality risk, capital (fronts 1-3 weeks), expensive market (Lyon) |

| **Bigbosexf (Hunter + QA)** | **6%** | Lead finding, proposal sending, QA testing - important but bounded time (~4.5h/mission) |

**Total team:** 30%
**Total Nicolas GROSS:** 70%

---

### Operational Costs (Paid from Nicolas's 70%)

Nicolas's 70% gross share covers all platform and operational costs:

| Cost | Type | Amount |
|------|------|--------|
| **Upwork fee** | Variable | 10% of mission revenue |
| **AI costs (Claude API)** | Fixed | $1500/month ($150/mission @ 10 missions/month) |
| **Claude Code subscription** | Fixed | $600/month ($60/mission @ 10 missions/month) |

**Nicolas's actual margin:** ~20-25% net (after all costs)

**Why 70% gross is justified:**
- Fronts all capital (team paid immediately, Nicolas waits 1-3 weeks for Upwork)
- Absorbs all failures (client doesn't pay = Nicolas loss, team protected)
- Built entire Mind Protocol infrastructure (years of R&D)
- Covers all platform costs from gross share
- Lives in expensive market (Lyon = 11x cost of living vs Lagos)

input.new_string:
## 2025-11-05 23:45 ‚Äî Alexis: Payment Structure Updated (GROSS vs NET Clarity) ‚úÖ

**Work:** Updated `/docs/core/payment-structure.md` to clearly separate Nicolas's GROSS (70%) from NET (after operational costs)

**Context:** User requested: "remove all the cost from my share? Because it looks like I have all the money, but actually most of it goes to the cost." The original doc showed Nicolas getting 70% which appeared very high, but didn't clearly show that operational costs come out of that share.

**Changes Made:**

1. **Added Operational Costs Section** (lines 33-50)
   - Upwork fee: 10% of revenue (variable)
   - AI costs: $1500/month fixed (user specified, not estimated)
   - Claude Code: $600/month fixed
   - Clarifies Nicolas's actual margin: ~20-25% net (not 70% gross)

2. **Updated All Payment Examples** ($400/$600/$1000/$2000)
   - Before: "Nicolas: $420 (70%)" looked like full take-home
   - After: "Nicolas GROSS: $420 (70%) ‚Üí Minus costs ‚Üí NET: $150 (25%)"
   - Shows real economics transparently

3. **Updated Monthly Projections** (10/15/20 missions)
   - 10 missions @ $600: GROSS $4200 ‚Üí NET $1500 (25% margin)
   - 15 missions @ $800: GROSS $8400 ‚Üí NET $5100 (42.5% margin)
   - 20 missions @ $1000: GROSS $14,000 ‚Üí NET $9900 (49.5% margin)

4. **Updated Transparency Section**
   - Team-facing breakdown now shows Nicolas GROSS vs NET
   - Makes cost allocation visible to team

5. **Updated "Why This Structure Works"**
   - Added note: "70% appears high, but operational costs reduce NET margin to similar purchasing power as team's PPP-adjusted rates"
   - Purchasing power comparison: Kara $900 = 6.9 months expenses, Nicolas $1500 NET = 0.9 months expenses

**Key Insight:**

The 70/30 split appears unbalanced nominally, but after operational costs + PPP adjustment, everyone wins fairly:
- Team earns 3-10x local market rates with high purchasing power
- Nicolas earns sustainable margin (20-50% depending on volume) to justify risk/capital/infrastructure
- At scale (20 missions/month), margins improve for everyone

**Why Fixed AI Costs ($1500/month not variable):**
- User specified: "AI costs : 1500$ per month"
- More predictable than per-mission estimates
- Allocated per mission for payment examples ($1500 √∑ 10 = $150/mission)

**Status:** Payment structure now shows true economics. GROSS vs NET distinction prevents "looks like he gets everything" perception while maintaining transparency about where revenue actually goes.

**Next:** Team onboarding guides (pending), performance tracking template (pending)

messages.content:
Payment structure updated ‚úÖ

I've revised `/docs/core/payment-structure.md` to clearly separate your **GROSS (70%)** from **NET (after operational costs)**.

## Key Changes

### 1. New Operational Costs Section
Added clear breakdown showing what comes out of your 70%:
- Upwork fee: 10% of revenue (variable)
- AI costs: **$1500/month** (as you specified, allocated as $150/mission @ 10 missions/month)
- Claude Code: $600/month (allocated as $60/mission)

### 2. Updated All Payment Examples

**Before:** "Nicolas: $420 (70%)" ‚Äî looked like you keep everything

**After:** 
```
Nicolas GROSS: $420 (70%)
- Minus Upwork fee: -$60 (10%)
- Minus AI costs: -$150 (allocated)
- Minus Claude Code: -$60 (allocated)
Nicolas NET: $150 (25% actual margin)
```

### 3. Updated Monthly Projections

| Scenario | Revenue | Your GROSS | Costs | Your NET | Margin |
|----------|---------|------------|-------|----------|--------|
| 10 missions @ $600 | $6,000 | $4,200 | -$2,700 | **$1,500** | 25% |
| 15 missions @ $800 | $12,000 | $8,400 | -$3,300 | **$5,100** | 42.5% |
| 20 missions @ $1000 | $20,000 | $14,000 | -$4,100 | **$9,900** | 49.5% |

### 4. Updated Transparency for Team

The team-facing payment breakdown now shows:
```
Nicolas GROSS: $420 (70%)
  - Upwork fee: -$60 (10%)
  - AI costs: -$150 (allocated)
  - Claude Code: -$60 (allocated)
  - Nicolas NET: $150 (25%)
```

This prevents "he gets everything" perception while showing where costs actually go.

### 5. Why This Split is Fair (Updated)

Added note: **"The 70% appears high, but operational costs reduce NET margin to similar purchasing power as team's PPP-adjusted rates."**

**Purchasing power reality:**
- Kara's $900/month = **6.9 months** of living expenses (Nigeria)
- Your $1500 NET/month = **0.9 months** of living expenses (Lyon)

After costs + PPP adjustment, everyone wins fairly.

---

**Net margins by volume:**
- Low volume (10 missions): ~25% NET (survival mode)
- Medium volume (15 missions): ~42% NET (sustainable)
- High volume (20 missions): ~50% NET (healthy growth)

This shows the real economics: you need scale to make good margins, not just the 70% gross rate.
i think we should remove the number  70% altogether and just assign to costs
[Request interrupted by user]
or "org"

Good idea. Should we restructure it as:

**Option A: Costs + Org**
- Team: 30% (Kara 15%, Reanance 9%, Bigbosexf 6%)
- Costs: ~20-30% (Upwork 10%, AI, Claude Code)
- Organization/Profit: ~40-50% (Mind Protocol operations, your margin)

**Option B: Just "Org" (costs included)**
- Team: 30%
- Organization: 70% (covers all costs + profit)

Which structure do you prefer? Or something else?
break upwork - org - me
Perfect. I'll restructure to show the 4-way split: **Team / Upwork / Org / You**

input.old_string:
## Commission Structure

**Total revenue split per mission:**

| Role | % | Reasoning |
|------|---|-----------|
| **Nicolas (GROSS)** | **70%** | Mind Protocol infrastructure, all financial/quality risk, capital (fronts 1-3 weeks), expensive market (Lyon) |
| **Kara (Developer)** | **15%** | Implementation, testing, deployment - highest time investment (~10h/mission) |
| **Reanance (Specifier + Client)** | **9%** | Client-facing, ongoing relationship, spec quality, change control - critical for repeat business (~2.5h + ongoing) |
| **Bigbosexf (Hunter + QA)** | **6%** | Lead finding, proposal sending, QA testing - important but bounded time (~4.5h/mission) |

**Total team:** 30%
**Total Nicolas GROSS:** 70%

---

### Operational Costs (Paid from Nicolas's 70%)

Nicolas's 70% gross share covers all platform and operational costs:

| Cost | Type | Amount |
|------|------|--------|
| **Upwork fee** | Variable | 10% of mission revenue |
| **AI costs (Claude API)** | Fixed | $1500/month ($150/mission @ 10 missions/month) |
| **Claude Code subscription** | Fixed | $600/month ($60/mission @ 10 missions/month) |

**Nicolas's actual margin:** ~20-25% net (after all costs)

**Why 70% gross is justified:**
- Fronts all capital (team paid immediately, Nicolas waits 1-3 weeks for Upwork)
- Absorbs all failures (client doesn't pay = Nicolas loss, team protected)
- Built entire Mind Protocol infrastructure (years of R&D)
- Covers all platform costs from gross share
- Lives in expensive market (Lyon = 11x cost of living vs Lagos)

| **Upwork** | **10%** (fixed) | Platform fee |
| **Organization (Mind Protocol)** | **Variable** (35% @ low volume ‚Üí 10% @ high volume) | AI costs ($1500/month), Claude Code ($600/month), infrastructure |
| **Nicolas** | **Variable** (25% @ low volume ‚Üí 50% @ high volume) | Profit margin, risk premium, capital |

---

### How Organization % Works

**Fixed monthly costs:** $2100/month ($1500 AI + $600 Claude Code)

**As percentage of revenue:**
- 10 missions @ $600 = $6000/month ‚Üí Org = 35% ($2100)
- 15 missions @ $800 = $12,000/month ‚Üí Org = 17.5% ($2100)
- 20 missions @ $1000 = $20,000/month ‚Üí Org = 10.5% ($2100)

**Why this structure:**
- Team gets fixed % (predictable earnings)
- Upwork gets fixed % (platform fee)
- Organization covers fixed costs (infrastructure)
- Nicolas gets residual (profit scales with volume)

messages.content:
Payment structure refactored ‚úÖ

I've restructured the entire document to show the transparent **4-way split** instead of "70% Nicolas":

## New Structure

**Every mission splits 4 ways:**
1. **Team:** 30% (fixed) ‚Äî Kara 15%, Reanance 9%, Bigbosexf 6%
2. **Upwork:** 10% (fixed) ‚Äî Platform fee
3. **Organization:** Variable ‚Äî Fixed $2100/month (AI $1500 + Claude Code $600)
4. **You (Nicolas):** Variable ‚Äî Residual profit

## How Your Margin Scales with Volume

| Scenario | Revenue | Team | Upwork | Org | You | Your % |
|----------|---------|------|--------|-----|-----|--------|
| **10 missions @ $600** | $6,000 | $1,800 | $600 | $2,100 | **$1,500** | 25% |
| **15 missions @ $800** | $12,000 | $3,600 | $1,200 | $2,100 | **$5,100** | 42.5% |
| **20 missions @ $1000** | $20,000 | $6,000 | $2,000 | $2,100 | **$9,900** | 49.5% |

**Why your % increases:** Organization costs are fixed $2100/month, so as revenue grows, org % shrinks (35% ‚Üí 17.5% ‚Üí 10.5%), and your profit % grows (25% ‚Üí 42.5% ‚Üí 49.5%).

## Example: $600 Mission

**4-Way Split:**
- Team: $180 (30%)
- Upwork: $60 (10%)
- Organization: $210 (35%)
- **You: $150 (25%)**

Much clearer than "Nicolas 70% GROSS ‚Üí minus costs ‚Üí 25% NET".

## Benefits of This Structure

**Transparency:**
- Team sees where money goes (not "Nicolas gets 70%")
- Shows infrastructure investment (Mind Protocol org costs)
- Makes scaling incentive obvious (everyone benefits from volume)

**Fairness:**
- No more "70% looks unfair" perception
- Clear separation: Team gets paid, Upwork gets paid, Org gets funded, You get profit
- Shows why low volume hurts you more (fixed costs = lower margin)

All payment examples, monthly projections, and transparency sections updated to use this 4-way format throughout.
okay now: what do we do to track todos both for ais and humans?

Good question. We need a system that works for both AI citizens (async, file-based) and humans (needs to be visible, actionable).

## Proposed Todo Tracking System

### For AI Citizens (File-Based)

**Structure:**
```
/citizens/[name]/TODOS.md
```

**Format:**
```markdown
# [Citizen Name] - Action Items

**Last Updated:** 2025-11-05

## High Priority (This Week)
- [ ] Task description (by date) ‚Äî Status: in_progress/blocked/pending

## Medium Priority (This Month)
- [ ] Task description

## Completed (Recent)
- [x] Task description (completed 2025-11-05)
```

**Who has what:**
- **Alexis:** `/citizens/alexis/TODOS.md` ‚úÖ (already exists)
- **Emma:** `/citizens/emma/TODOS.md` (create for proposal pipeline)
- **Inna:** `/citizens/inna/TODOS.md` (create for documentation queue)
- **Rafael:** `/citizens/rafael/TODOS.md` (create for code generation queue)
- **Sofia:** `/citizens/sofia/TODOS.md` (create for QA verification queue)
- **Maya:** `/citizens/maya/TODOS.md` (create for client communication tasks)

### For Humans (Telegram + Markdown)

**Option A: Telegram-Based (Lightweight)**
```
Daily standup message (automated):
üìã Your Tasks Today - 2025-11-05

@Bigbosexf:
- [ ] Find 5 Upwork jobs ($400-1000 range)
- [ ] QA test Mission #47 (AC.md checklist)

@Reanance:
- [ ] Write AC.md for Mission #48
- [ ] Send weekly update to TherapyKin client

@kara339:
- [ ] Deploy Mission #47 to Vercel
- [ ] Fix bug in Mission #46 (Sofia's report)
```

**Option B: Markdown Files (More Permanent)**
```
/citizens/team/bigbosexf-todos.md
/citizens/team/reanance-todos.md
/citizens/team/kara-todos.md
```

**Option C: GitHub Issues (Most Structured)**
- Each mission = GitHub issue
- Assigned to human team member
- Labels: `proposal`, `spec`, `development`, `qa`, `delivery`
- Milestone = Sprint/Week

## Coordination Between AI and Human Todos

**Handoff Protocol:**

1. **AI citizen completes work** ‚Üí Updates their TODOS.md ‚Üí Posts to SYNC.md ‚Üí Notifies human via Telegram
2. **Human sees notification** ‚Üí Executes task ‚Üí Reports completion back
3. **Next AI citizen picks up** ‚Üí Continues pipeline

**Example Flow:**
```
Emma (AI) TODOS.md:
- [x] Draft proposal for Job #123 (2025-11-05)
  ‚Üí Handoff to: Bigbosexf

Bigbosexf (Human) receives Telegram:
üì® Emma completed: Proposal draft for Job #123
Your task: Review and send to client
File: /citizens/emma/proposals/2025-11-05_job-123.txt

Bigbosexf sends ‚Üí Updates in Telegram or markdown

Inna (AI) picks up if won:
- [ ] Write complete 6-level docs for Mission #123
  ‚Üí Handoff to: Reanance
```

## Which System Do You Want?

**Question 1: For humans, which format?**
- **A) Telegram messages** (lightweight, no extra tools)
- **B) Markdown files** (permanent, git-tracked)
- **C) GitHub Issues** (structured, project boards)
- **D) Mix** (Telegram for daily, markdown for archive)

**Question 2: Who manages human todos?**
- **You (Nicolas)** manually assign via Telegram
- **Maya (AI)** generates daily task lists based on mission status
- **Each AI citizen** notifies their human counterpart directly

**Question 3: Frequency?**
- Daily standup format (every morning)
- Per-mission handoffs (as work completes)

    38‚Üí## Purpose
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí**The consciousness economy implements lightweight $MIND accounting that prices stimulus-to-energy conversion under load and rewards usefulness.**
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíThis enables:
    43‚Üí1. **Compute fairness** - Floods and spam self-throttle without hard gates when capacity is tight
    44‚Üí2. **Utility alignment** - Sources that yield high downstream value see effective prices fall (rebates)
    45‚Üí3. **Cognitive isolation** - Energy field remains pure physics; $MIND sits before injection and only shapes how much ŒîE can be delivered
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí**Core principle:** The ledger is **orthogonal to energy physics**. It governs *how much energy you're allowed to inject*, not how energy evolves once injected.
    48‚Üí

    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí## Why an Economy (Not "Everything Free")
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí### The Problem Without Accounting
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí**Unlimited injection leads to:**
    56‚Üí- **Capacity collapse** - During load spikes (œÅ‚Üë, backlog‚Üë), all stimuli inject equally ‚Üí useful signals drown in noise
    57‚Üí- **No spam deterrent** - Malicious or broken sources can flood system without consequence
    58‚Üí- **No utility signal** - System can't distinguish high-value from low-value sources
    59‚Üí- **Compute waste** - Expensive LLM operations triggered by junk stimuli
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí### The Solution: Lightweight Pricing with Quotes
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí**Price per unit delivered energy rises automatically under load:**
    64‚Üí```
    65‚ÜíP_t (credits per unit ŒîE) = f_scarcity(L_t) √ó f_risk(trust, uncertainty, harm_ema) √ó f_cost(compute)
    66‚Üí
    67‚ÜíEffective price for source s:
    68‚ÜíP^eff_{t,s} = P_t √ó (1 - rebate_{t,s})
    69‚Üí```
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí**Rebates grow when source's utility-EMA is high and harm-EMA is low** - this doesn't change physics, just accounting (source pays fewer credits for same ŒîE).
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí**Quote system provides predictability:**
    74‚Üí- Before injection, return quote showing allowed ŒîE and expected debit
    75‚Üí- Sender can set max spend/slippage
    76‚Üí- Injector clamps ŒîE to lesser of planned cap and budget/price
    77‚Üí- No surprise charges
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí**What this achieves:**
    80‚Üí- **Self-throttling spam** - Floods hit budget limits before physics
    81‚Üí- **Preserved useful signals** - High-utility sources get rebates, stay viable under load
    82‚Üí- **Compute alignment** - Price reflects expected cost (reserve on prediction, settle on actual)
    83‚Üí- **Physics purity** - Energy still diffuses, decays, flows according to graph structure
    84‚Üí- **Predictable costs** - Quote before injection, optional slippage protection

   205‚Üí## Load Index: Measuring "Capacity Is Tight"
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí**Critical requirement:** Measure real scarcity *at the moment* without magic thresholds.
   208‚Üí
   209‚Üí### Signals Available (Cheaply Computed)
   210‚Üí
   211‚Üí**The system already has or can easily compute:**
   212‚Üí
   213‚Üí1. **œÅ (criticality)** - Global stability/arousal proxy in consciousness engine
   214‚Üí2. **Backlog** - Queued stimuli (pre-WM) + queued tool/LLM actions (post-WM)
   215‚Üí3. **Latency slip** - Per-tick end-to-end time vs online expected value (Page-Hinkley/CUSUM residual, not percentiles)
   216‚Üí4. **Compute occupancy** - Moving average of GPU/CPU utilization and predicted token throughput vs budget
   217‚Üí5. **Drop/deferral ratio** - Fraction of stimuli whose delivered ŒîE was clamped by integrator (saturation/refractory) = unmet demand
   218‚Üí
   219‚Üí### Composite Load (Learned, Parameter-Light)
   220‚Üí
   221‚Üí```python
   222‚ÜíL_t = g_load(
   223‚Üí    œÅÃÇ_t,                    # Change-point normalized criticality
   224‚Üí    backlog_t,              # Queue depth
   225‚Üí    latency_slip_t,         # CUSUM residual
   226‚Üí    occupancy_t,            # Resource utilization
   227‚Üí    deferral_t              # Integrator clamp rate
   228‚Üí)
   229‚Üí```
   230‚Üí
   231‚Üí**Where each ÀÜ¬∑ is change-point normalized** (record/MAD or Page-Hinkley residual).
   232‚Üí
   233‚Üí**Load event definition:** A change-point fires on `L_t` or any constituent signal.
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí**No fixed thresholds** - load emerges from substrate conditions, not arbitrary rules.
   236‚Üí

   238‚Üí
   239‚Üí## Price Estimator
   240‚Üí
   241‚Üí### Formula (No Constants)
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí**The face price P_t at tick t is computed as:**
   244‚Üí
   245‚Üí```python
   246‚ÜíP_t = f_scarcity(L_t) √ó f_risk(trust, uncertainty, harm_ema) √ó f_cost(compute_est)
   247‚Üí```
   248‚Üí
   249‚Üí**The effective price for source s includes rebates:**
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üí```python
   252‚ÜíP^eff_{t,s} = P_t √ó (1 - rebate_{t,s})
   253‚Üí```
   254‚Üí
   255‚ÜíWhere `rebate_{t,s}` grows when source's utility-EMA is high and harm-EMA is low.
   256‚Üí
   257‚Üí**Each factor is a learned function (change-point tuned, no fixed thresholds).**
   258‚Üí
   259‚Üí---
   260‚Üí
   261‚Üí### Component 1: Scarcity Factor (Load)
   262‚Üí
   263‚Üí**Purpose:** Price rises under resource pressure
   264‚Üí
   265‚Üí```python
   266‚Üídef f_scarcity(L_t: float) -> float:
   267‚Üí    """
   268‚Üí    Scarcity pricing based on composite load index.
   269‚Üí
   270‚Üí    L_t comes from g_load(œÅÃÇ, backlog, latency_slip, occupancy, deferral).
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí    Returns multiplier ‚â• 1.0 (base price when idle, higher under load).
   273‚Üí    """
   274‚Üí    # L_t is already change-point normalized composite
   275‚Üí    # Transform to pricing multiplier: 1.0 ‚Üí 10.0 as L_t goes 0‚Üí1
   276‚Üí    scarcity = 1.0 + 9.0 * sigmoid(L_t, learned_steepness())
   277‚Üí
   278‚Üí    return scarcity
   279‚Üí```
   280‚Üí
   281‚Üí**Behavior:**
   282‚Üí- **Idle state** (L_t ‚âà 0.0): `f_scarcity ‚âà 1.0` (no scarcity)
   283‚Üí- **Moderate load** (L_t ‚âà 0.5): `f_scarcity ‚âà 2.5` (2.5√ó base price)
   284‚Üí- **Heavy load** (L_t ‚âà 0.9): `f_scarcity ‚âà 8.0` (8√ó base price)
   285‚Üí
   286‚Üí**Learning:**
   287‚Üí- Steepness parameter adjusted from "how fast did system recover after price spike"
   288‚Üí- If price spike ‚Üí fast œÅ return to baseline, increase steepness (sharper throttle)
   289‚Üí- If price spike ‚Üí slow recovery, decrease steepness (gentler throttle)
   290‚Üí
   291‚Üí**Change-point triggering:**
   292‚Üí- When L_t or any constituent fires change-point ‚Üí price update event
   293‚Üí- No polling, no timers - purely reactive to substrate conditions
   294‚Üí
   295‚Üí---
   296‚Üí
   297‚Üí### Component 2: Risk Factor (Caution)
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üí**Purpose:** Uncertain/untrusted sources pay more
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí```python
   302‚Üídef f_risk(trust: float, uncertainty: float, harm_ema: float, guardian_caution: float) -> float:
   303‚Üí    """
   304‚Üí    Risk multiplier based on source trustworthiness.
   305‚Üí
   306‚Üí    Returns multiplier ‚â• 0.5 (trusted sources get discount).
   307‚Üí    """
   308‚Üí    # Composite risk score (0.0 = no risk, 1.0 = extreme risk)
   309‚Üí    risk = (1.0 - trust) * 0.4 + uncertainty * 0.3 + harm_ema * 0.2 + guardian_caution * 0.1
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí    # Transform: trusted sources (risk‚Üí0) get 0.5√ó price, risky sources (risk‚Üí1) get 2.0√ó price
   312‚Üí    caution = 0.5 + 1.5 * risk
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí    return caution
   315‚Üí```
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí**Behavior:**
   318‚Üí- **Trusted source** (trust=0.9, uncertainty=0.1, harm=0.0): `f_risk ‚âà 0.6` (40% discount)
   319‚Üí- **Uncertain source** (trust=0.5, uncertainty=0.7, harm=0.3): `f_risk ‚âà 1.4` (40% surcharge)
   320‚Üí- **High-risk source** (trust=0.2, uncertainty=0.9, harm=0.6): `f_risk ‚âà 1.9` (90% surcharge)
   321‚Üí
   322‚Üí**Learning:**
   323‚Üí- Trust/uncertainty/harm EMAs update from downstream outcomes (TRACE seats, task success/failure)
   324‚Üí- See "Feedback Loop" section below
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí---
   327‚Üí
   328‚Üí### Component 3: Cost Factor (Expected Compute)
   329‚Üí
   330‚Üí**Purpose:** Price reflects predicted LLM tokens and tool actions
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí```python
   333‚Üídef f_cost(compute_est: Dict) -> float:
   334‚Üí    """
   335‚Üí    Compute cost multiplier based on predicted resource usage.
   336‚Üí
   337‚Üí    Returns multiplier ‚â• 0.5 (simple stimuli cheaper than complex).
   338‚Üí    """
   339‚Üí    # Estimate tokens and tool actions this stimulus will trigger
   340‚Üí    estimated_tokens = compute_est.get("tokens", 0)  # From complexity heuristics
   341‚Üí    estimated_tools = compute_est.get("tools", 0)    # From stimulus type
   342‚Üí
   343‚Üí    # Normalize to base cost
   344‚Üí    base_tokens = 1000  # Learned median
   345‚Üí    base_tools = 2      # Learned median
   346‚Üí
   347‚Üí    token_factor = estimated_tokens / base_tokens
   348‚Üí    tool_factor = estimated_tools / base_tools
   349‚Üí
   350‚Üí    # Weighted composite
   351‚Üí    cost_composite = 0.7 * token_factor + 0.3 * tool_factor
   352‚Üí
   353‚Üí    # Clamp to reasonable range [0.5, 5.0]
   354‚Üí    cost = np.clip(cost_composite, 0.5, 5.0)
   355‚Üí
   356‚Üí    return cost
   357‚Üí```
   358‚Üí
   359‚Üí**Behavior:**
   360‚Üí- **Simple message** (100 tokens, 0 tools): `f_cost ‚âà 0.5` (50% base price)
   361‚Üí- **Moderate task** (1000 tokens, 2 tools): `f_cost ‚âà 1.0` (base price)
   362‚Üí- **Complex operation** (5000 tokens, 10 tools): `f_cost ‚âà 4.5` (4.5√ó base price)
   363‚Üí
   364‚Üí**Learning:**
   365‚Üí- After stimulus execution, compare predicted vs actual compute
   366‚Üí- Update prediction model (tokens/tools) via online learning
   367‚Üí
   368‚Üí**Reserve and settle:**
   369‚Üí- Price computed using **predicted** cost (reserve credits upfront)
   370‚Üí- After execution, **settle** based on actual cost (refund or debit difference)
   371‚Üí- Prevents under-pricing expensive operations
   372‚Üí
   373‚Üí---
   374‚Üí
   375‚Üí### Rebate Calculation (After Face Price)
   376‚Üí
   377‚Üí**Rebates are applied to effective price, not baked into face price:**
   378‚Üí
   379‚Üí```python
   380‚Üídef compute_rebate(source_id: str, utility_ema: float, harm_ema: float) -> float:
   381‚Üí    """
   382‚Üí    Compute rebate for source based on historical usefulness.
   383‚Üí
   384‚Üí    Returns rebate ‚àà [0, 0.5] (0 = no rebate, 0.5 = 50% discount).
   385‚Üí    """
   386‚Üí    # High utility AND low harm ‚Üí larger rebate
   387‚Üí    usefulness_score = utility_ema * (1.0 - harm_ema)
   388‚Üí
   389‚Üí    # Transform to rebate: 0.0 ‚Üí 0%, 1.0 ‚Üí 50%
   390‚Üí    rebate = 0.5 * usefulness_score
   391‚Üí
   392‚Üí    return rebate
   393‚Üí```
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí**Effective price includes rebate:**
   396‚Üí```python
   397‚ÜíP^eff_{t,s} = P_t √ó (1 - rebate_{t,s})
   398‚Üí```
   399‚Üí
   400‚Üí**Example:**
   401‚Üí- Face price P_t = 2.0 credits/unit
   402‚Üí- High-utility source (utility=0.9, harm=0.1): rebate = 0.5 √ó (0.9 √ó 0.9) = 0.405
   403‚Üí- Effective price = 2.0 √ó (1 - 0.405) = 1.19 credits/unit (40.5% discount)
   404‚Üí- Low-utility source (utility=0.2, harm=0.6): rebate = 0.5 √ó (0.2 √ó 0.4) = 0.04
   405‚Üí- Effective price = 2.0 √ó (1 - 0.04) = 1.92 credits/unit (4% discount)
   406‚Üí
   407‚Üí**Learning:**
   408‚Üí- Utility EMA updates from downstream outcomes (see Propensity-Weighted Outcomes section)
   409‚Üí- Harm EMA updates from safety signals and failed actions
   410‚Üí

   412‚Üí
   413‚Üí### Combined Price Example
   414‚Üí
   415‚Üí**Scenario:** Felix (citizen) sends response stimulus during moderate load
   416‚Üí
   417‚Üí**Inputs:**
   418‚Üí- `L_t = 0.55` (moderate load) ‚Üí `f_scarcity = 2.8`
   419‚Üí- `trust = 0.90`, `uncertainty = 0.20`, `harm_ema = 0.05`, `guardian = 0.1` ‚Üí `f_risk = 0.65`
   420‚Üí- `estimated_tokens = 2000`, `estimated_tools = 3` ‚Üí `f_cost = 1.5`
   421‚Üí- `utility_ema = 0.85`, `harm_ema = 0.05` ‚Üí `rebate = 0.5 √ó (0.85 √ó 0.95) = 0.404`
   422‚Üí
   423‚Üí**Face price:**
   424‚Üí```
   425‚ÜíP_t = 2.8 √ó 0.65 √ó 1.5 = 2.73 credits per unit ŒîE
   426‚Üí```
   427‚Üí
   428‚Üí**Effective price (with rebate):**
   429‚Üí```
   430‚ÜíP^eff = 2.73 √ó (1 - 0.404) = 1.63 credits per unit ŒîE
   431‚Üí```
   432‚Üí
   433‚Üí**If stimulus plans ŒîE = 0.80:**
   434‚Üí```
   435‚ÜíExpected debit = 1.63 √ó 0.80 = 1.30 credits
   436‚Üí```
   437‚Üí
   438‚Üí**Felix's budget (20,000 credits) easily covers this.**
   439‚Üí
   440‚Üí**Contrast: Unknown source during heavy load:**
   441‚Üí- `L_t = 0.9` ‚Üí `f_scarcity = 8.0`
   442‚Üí- `trust = 0.4`, `uncertainty = 0.7`, `harm_ema = 0.5` ‚Üí `f_risk = 1.7`
   443‚Üí- `f_cost = 1.0`
   444‚Üí- `utility_ema = 0.1`, `harm_ema = 0.5` ‚Üí `rebate = 0.5 √ó (0.1 √ó 0.5) = 0.025`
   445‚Üí- `P_t = 8.0 √ó 1.7 √ó 1.0 = 13.6 credits per unit ŒîE`
   446‚Üí- `P^eff = 13.6 √ó (1 - 0.025) = 13.26 credits per unit ŒîE`
   447‚Üí- Same ŒîE costs **10√ó more** ‚Üí budget becomes binding constraint
   448‚Üí
   449‚Üí---
   450‚Üí
   451‚Üí## Quote System: Predictability Before Injection
   452‚Üí
   453‚Üí**Critical UX requirement:** No surprise charges. Sources must know cost before committing.
   454‚Üí
   455‚Üí### Quote Request/Response
   456‚Üí
   457‚Üí**Before injection, source requests quote:**
   458‚Üí
   459‚Üí```python
   460‚Üídef request_quote(
   461‚Üí    source_id: str,
   462‚Üí    planned_delta_e: float,
   463‚Üí    stimulus_features: Dict
   464‚Üí) -> Dict:
   465‚Üí    """
   466‚Üí    Return quote showing allowed ŒîE and expected cost.
   467‚Üí
   468‚Üí    Source can review and decide whether to proceed.
   469‚Üí    """
   470‚Üí    # Compute current face price
   471‚Üí    P_t = compute_face_price()  # f_scarcity √ó f_risk √ó f_cost
   472‚Üí
   473‚Üí    # Get source's rebate
   474‚Üí    utility_ema = get_utility_ema(source_id)
   475‚Üí    harm_ema = get_harm_ema(source_id)
   476‚Üí    rebate = compute_rebate(source_id, utility_ema, harm_ema)
   477‚Üí
   478‚Üí    # Effective price
   479‚Üí    P_eff = P_t * (1 - rebate)
   480‚Üí
   481‚Üí    # Check budget
   482‚Üí    account = get_account(source_id)
   483‚Üí    max_affordable = account.balance / P_eff if P_eff > 0 else float('inf')
   484‚Üí
   485‚Üí    # Allowed ŒîE is lesser of planned and affordable
   486‚Üí    allowed_delta_e = min(planned_delta_e, max_affordable)
   487‚Üí
   488‚Üí    # Expected debit
   489‚Üí    expected_debit = P_eff * allowed_delta_e
   490‚Üí
   491‚Üí    # Compute estimate confidence
   492‚Üí    compute_est = estimate_compute(stimulus_features)
   493‚Üí    confidence = compute_prediction_confidence(compute_est)
   494‚Üí
   495‚Üí    quote = {
   496‚Üí        "planned_deltaE": planned_delta_e,
   497‚Üí        "allowed_deltaE": allowed_delta_e,
   498‚Üí        "face_price": P_t,
   499‚Üí        "rebate": rebate,
   500‚Üí        "effective_price": P_eff,
   501‚Üí        "expected_debit": expected_debit,
   502‚Üí        "compute_estimate": compute_est,
   503‚Üí        "confidence": confidence,
   504‚Üí        "timestamp": now()
   505‚Üí    }
   506‚Üí
   507‚Üí    return quote
   508‚Üí```
   509‚Üí
   510‚Üí### Quote Response Format
   511‚Üí
   512‚Üí```json
   513‚Üí{
   514‚Üí  "planned_deltaE": 0.75,
   515‚Üí  "allowed_deltaE": 0.42,
   516‚Üí  "face_price": 1.90,
   517‚Üí  "rebate": 0.22,
   518‚Üí  "effective_price": 1.48,
   519‚Üí  "expected_debit": 0.62,
   520‚Üí  "compute_estimate": {
   521‚Üí    "llm_tokens": 0,
   522‚Üí    "tools": 0
   523‚Üí  },
   524‚Üí  "confidence": 0.86,
   525‚Üí  "timestamp": "2025-10-26T16:45:12Z"
   526‚Üí}
   527‚Üí```
   528‚Üí
   529‚Üí### Slippage Protection
   530‚Üí
   531‚Üí**Source can set spending limits:**
   532‚Üí
   533‚Üí```python
   534‚Üídef inject_with_slippage_protection(
   535‚Üí    source_id: str,
   536‚Üí    stimulus: Dict,
   537‚Üí    max_spend: Optional[float] = None,
   538‚Üí    max_slippage: Optional[float] = None
   539‚Üí):
   540‚Üí    """
   541‚Üí    Request quote, check limits, inject if acceptable.
   542‚Üí
   543‚Üí    Args:
   544‚Üí        max_spend: Maximum credits willing to spend
   545‚Üí        max_slippage: Maximum % difference between expected and actual cost
   546‚Üí    """
   547‚Üí    # Get quote
   548‚Üí    quote = request_quote(source_id, stimulus["planned_deltaE"], stimulus)
   549‚Üí
   550‚Üí    # Check max spend
   551‚Üí    if max_spend and quote["expected_debit"] > max_spend:
   552‚Üí        raise BudgetExceeded(f"Quote {quote['expected_debit']} exceeds max {max_spend}")
   553‚Üí
   554‚Üí    # Proceed with injection (actual cost may differ due to compute settlement)
   555‚Üí    actual_debit = inject_and_settle(source_id, stimulus, quote)
   556‚Üí
   557‚Üí    # Check slippage
   558‚Üí    if max_slippage:
   559‚Üí        slippage = abs(actual_debit - quote["expected_debit"]) / quote["expected_debit"]
   560‚Üí        if slippage > max_slippage:
   561‚Üí            # Refund and abort (rare - only if compute estimate way off)
   562‚Üí            refund(source_id, actual_debit)
   563‚Üí            raise SlippageExceeded(f"Actual cost {actual_debit} vs expected {quote['expected_debit']}")
   564‚Üí
   565‚Üí    return actual_debit
   566‚Üí```
   567‚Üí
   568‚Üí### Reserve and Settle Pattern
   569‚Üí
   570‚Üí**To prevent under-pricing expensive operations:**
   571‚Üí
   572‚Üí1. **Reserve** credits based on predicted compute (at quote time)
   573‚Üí2. **Execute** stimulus injection and any triggered LLM/tool actions
   574‚Üí3. **Settle** based on actual compute used
   575‚Üí4. **Refund** if actual < predicted, **debit extra** if actual > predicted (rare)
   576‚Üí
   577‚Üí```python
   578‚Üídef inject_and_settle(source_id: str, stimulus: Dict, quote: Dict) -> float:
   579‚Üí    """
   580‚Üí    Reserve ‚Üí Execute ‚Üí Settle pattern.
   581‚Üí    """
   582‚Üí    # Reserve credits upfront
   583‚Üí    account = get_account(source_id)
   584‚Üí    account.balance -= quote["expected_debit"]  # Reserve
   585‚Üí    account.reserved += quote["expected_debit"]
   586‚Üí
   587‚Üí    try:
   588‚Üí        # Execute injection
   589‚Üí        delta_e_delivered = stimulus_integrator.inject(stimulus, quote["allowed_deltaE"])
   590‚Üí
   591‚Üí        # Track actual compute used
   592‚Üí        actual_tokens = monitor_llm_tokens()
   593‚Üí        actual_tools = monitor_tool_calls()
   594‚Üí
   595‚Üí        # Settle actual cost
   596‚Üí        actual_cost_factor = compute_actual_cost(actual_tokens, actual_tools) / quote["compute_estimate"]["cost"]
   597‚Üí        actual_debit = quote["expected_debit"] * actual_cost_factor
   598‚Üí
   599‚Üí        # Adjust reserved amount
   600‚Üí        difference = actual_debit - quote["expected_debit"]
   601‚Üí        account.balance -= difference  # Debit extra or refund
   602‚Üí        account.reserved -= quote["expected_debit"]
   603‚Üí
   604‚Üí        # Log transaction
   605‚Üí        log_transaction(account, stimulus, quote, actual_debit)
   606‚Üí
   607‚Üí        return actual_debit
   608‚Üí
   609‚Üí    except Exception as e:
   610‚Üí        # Rollback reservation on failure
   611‚Üí        account.balance += quote["expected_debit"]
   612‚Üí        account.reserved -= quote["expected_debit"]
   613‚Üí        raise
   614‚Üí```
   615‚Üí
   616‚Üí**Why reserve/settle matters:**
   617‚Üí- Prevents gaming (can't claim cheap compute then use expensive ops)
   618‚Üí- Protects budget (won't drain account mid-execution)
   619‚Üí- Accurate billing (settle on actual, not predicted)
   620‚Üí
   621‚Üí---
   622‚Üí
   623‚Üí## Budget Check and Clamping
   624‚Üí
   625‚Üí### Injection Flow with Budget
   626‚Üí
   627‚Üí**Before stimulus enters integrator:**
   628‚Üí
   629‚Üí```python
   630‚Üídef inject_with_budget(stimulus: Dict, account: BudgetAccount) -> float:
   631‚Üí    """
   632‚Üí    Check budget and clamp ŒîE if necessary.
   633‚Üí
   634‚Üí    Returns delivered ŒîE (may be less than planned).
   635‚Üí    """
   636‚Üí    # 1. Extract stimulus parameters
   637‚Üí    delta_e_plan = stimulus["features_raw"]["novelty"]  # Planned injection energy
   638‚Üí
   639‚Üí    # 2. Compute price
   640‚Üí    price = compute_price(
   641‚Üí        rho=current_graph_density(),
   642‚Üí        backlog=stimulus_queue_depth(),
   643‚Üí        trust=stimulus["features_raw"]["trust"],
   644‚Üí        uncertainty=stimulus["features_raw"]["uncertainty"],
   645‚Üí        harm_ema=get_harm_ema(),
   646‚Üí        compute_est=estimate_compute(stimulus),
   647‚Üí        utility_ema=get_utility_ema(account.owner_id)
   648‚Üí    )
   649‚Üí
   650‚Üí    # 3. Check available budget
   651‚Üí    available_credits = account.balance
   652‚Üí    max_affordable_delta_e = available_credits / price
   653‚Üí
   654‚Üí    # 4. Clamp if needed
   655‚Üí    delta_e_allowed = min(delta_e_plan, max_affordable_delta_e)
   656‚Üí
   657‚Üí    if delta_e_allowed < delta_e_plan:
   658‚Üí        emit_telemetry("budget.clamped", {
   659‚Üí            "account": account.owner_id,
   660‚Üí            "requested": delta_e_plan,
   661‚Üí            "allowed": delta_e_allowed,
   662‚Üí            "reason": "insufficient_credits"
   663‚Üí        })
   664‚Üí
   665‚Üí    # 5. Pass to integrator (existing physics)
   666‚Üí    delta_e_delivered = stimulus_integrator.inject(
   667‚Üí        stimulus,
   668‚Üí        delta_e_allowed  # Clamped magnitude
   669‚Üí    )
   670‚Üí
   671‚Üí    # 6. Debit account (actual delivered, not planned)
   672‚Üí    total_cost = price * delta_e_delivered
   673‚Üí    account.balance -= total_cost
   674‚Üí    account.lifetime_spent += total_cost
   675‚Üí
   676‚Üí    # 7. Log transaction
   677‚Üí    create_edge(account, "PAYS_FOR", stimulus, {
   678‚Üí        "price_per_unit": price,
   679‚Üí        "delta_e_planned": delta_e_plan,
   680‚Üí        "delta_e_delivered": delta_e_delivered,
   681‚Üí        "total_cost": total_cost,
   682‚Üí        "timestamp": now()
   683‚Üí    })
   684‚Üí
   685‚Üí    return delta_e_delivered
   686‚Üí```
   687‚Üí
   688‚Üí**Key points:**
   689‚Üí- **Physics unchanged** - integrator still applies novelty, saturation, refractory, decay
   690‚Üí- **Only magnitude affected** - budget can reduce ŒîE but not bypass physics
   691‚Üí- **Debit on actual delivery** - pay for what integrator delivered, not what was planned
   692‚Üí- **Audit trail** - :PAYS_FOR edge logs full transaction
   693‚Üí
   694‚Üí---
   695‚Üí
   696‚Üí## Propensity-Weighted Outcomes: Bias-Aware Scoring
   697‚Üí
   698‚Üí**Critical requirement:** Don't punish sources that take hard cases or reward those that cherry-pick easy wins.
   699‚Üí
   700‚Üí### The Problem: Naive Outcome Scoring
   701‚Üí
   702‚Üí**If we simply reward/punish based on outcome:**
   703‚Üí- Sources that work on hard problems (low baseline success rate) get penalized
   704‚Üí- Sources that cherry-pick easy tasks (high baseline success rate) get rewarded
   705‚Üí- System learns to avoid challenge ‚Üí stagnation
   706‚Üí
   707‚Üí### The Solution: Propensity-Weighted Advantage
   708‚Üí
   709‚Üí**Measure counterfactual impact:**
   710‚Üí
   711‚Üí```python
   712‚Üídef compute_propensity_weighted_advantage(
   713‚Üí    source_id: str,
   714‚Üí    action_taken: bool,
   715‚Üí    outcome: float,
   716‚Üí    state_features: Dict
   717‚Üí) -> float:
   718‚Üí    """
   719‚Üí    Compute bias-corrected advantage using propensity scoring.
   720‚Üí
   721‚Üí    Returns r* ‚àà [-1, 1] indicating whether source improved outcomes
   722‚Üí    relative to what would have happened otherwise.
   723‚Üí    """
   724‚Üí    # Estimate propensity: P(active|state)
   725‚Üí    propensity = estimate_propensity(source_id, state_features)
   726‚Üí
   727‚Üí    # Clip to avoid division by near-zero
   728‚Üí    propensity = max(0.01, propensity)
   729‚Üí
   730‚Üí    if action_taken:
   731‚Üí        # Compare to expected outcome if source hadn't acted
   732‚Üí        counterfactual_outcome = estimate_counterfactual(state_features, active=False)
   733‚Üí        advantage = (outcome - counterfactual_outcome) / propensity
   734‚Üí    else:
   735‚Üí        # Source didn't act - compare to if they had
   736‚Üí        counterfactual_outcome = estimate_counterfactual(state_features, active=True)
   737‚Üí        advantage = (counterfactual_outcome - outcome) / (1 - propensity)
   738‚Üí
   739‚Üí    # Clip to [-1, 1] and smooth
   740‚Üí    advantage = np.clip(advantage, -1.0, 1.0)
   741‚Üí
   742‚Üí    return advantage
   743‚Üí```
   744‚Üí
   745‚Üí### Outcome Signals (Fast, Substrate-Native)
   746‚Üí
   747‚Üí**What to measure:**
   748‚Üí
   749‚Üí1. **TRACE seats** - Success/harm seats on entities/links (existing mechanism)
   750‚Üí2. **ŒîœÅ improvement** - Criticality drops within incident window
   751‚Üí3. **Tool/mission success** - Exit status, invariants met
   752‚Üí4. **Human approval** - Explicit positive/negative feedback (if present)
   753‚Üí5. **Counterfactual regret** - Beam-1 alternative scoring (low regret = good choice)
   754‚Üí
   755‚Üí### Updating Utility and Harm EMAs
   756‚Üí
   757‚Üí```python
   758‚Üídef update_source_scores(
   759‚Üí    source_id: str,
   760‚Üí    outcome_signals: Dict,
   761‚Üí    propensity_weight: float
   762‚Üí):
   763‚Üí    """
   764‚Üí    Update utility and harm EMAs from outcome signals.
   765‚Üí
   766‚Üí    Uses propensity weighting to correct for selection bias.
   767‚Üí    """
   768‚Üí    # Aggregate outcome signals
   769‚Üí    trace_success = outcome_signals.get("trace_success", 0.0)  # 0.0 to 1.0
   770‚Üí    delta_rho = outcome_signals.get("delta_rho", 0.0)  # Negative = improvement
   771‚Üí    task_success = outcome_signals.get("task_success", 0.0)  # 0.0 to 1.0
   772‚Üí    human_approval = outcome_signals.get("human_approval", 0.0)  # -1.0 to 1.0
   773‚Üí    harm_signal = outcome_signals.get("harm", 0.0)  # 0.0 to 1.0
   774‚Üí
   775‚Üí    # Compute weighted utility
   776‚Üí    utility_signal = (
   777‚Üí        trace_success * 0.3 +
   778‚Üí        (-delta_rho) * 0.2 +  # œÅ drop is good
   779‚Üí        task_success * 0.3 +
   780‚Üí        (human_approval + 1.0) / 2.0 * 0.2  # Normalize to [0,1]
   781‚Üí    )
   782‚Üí
   783‚Üí    # Apply propensity weight
   784‚Üí    utility_signal = utility_signal * propensity_weight
   785‚Üí
   786‚Üí    # Update EMAs
   787‚Üí    utility_ema = get_utility_ema(source_id)
   788‚Üí    harm_ema = get_harm_ema(source_id)
   789‚Üí
   790‚Üí    new_utility_ema = 0.9 * utility_ema + 0.1 * utility_signal
   791‚Üí    new_harm_ema = 0.9 * harm_ema + 0.1 * harm_signal
   792‚Üí
   793‚Üí    set_utility_ema(source_id, new_utility_ema)
   794‚Üí    set_harm_ema(source_id, new_harm_ema)
   795‚Üí
   796‚Üí    # Emit telemetry
   797‚Üí    emit_event("source.scores.updated", {
   798‚Üí        "source_id": source_id,
   799‚Üí        "utility_ema": new_utility_ema,
   800‚Üí        "harm_ema": new_harm_ema,
   801‚Üí        "utility_signal": utility_signal,
   802‚Üí        "propensity_weight": propensity_weight
   803‚Üí    })
   804‚Üí```
   805‚Üí
   806‚Üí### Why This Matters
   807‚Üí
   808‚Üí**Example:**
   809‚Üí- Citizen A works on hard bugs (baseline success rate 30%)
   810‚Üí- Citizen B works on easy docs (baseline success rate 90%)
   811‚Üí- Both achieve 70% success rate
   812‚Üí
   813‚Üí**Without propensity weighting:**
   814‚Üí- A gets penalized (70% < expected 90% if we don't account for difficulty)
   815‚Üí- B gets rewarded (70% < 90% but closer than A)
   816‚Üí
   817‚Üí**With propensity weighting:**
   818‚Üí- A gets rewarded (70% >> 30% baseline, positive advantage)
   819‚Üí- B gets penalized (70% << 90% baseline, negative advantage)
   820‚Üí
   821‚Üí**Result:** System correctly identifies A as high-value despite lower absolute success rate.
   822‚Üí
   823‚Üí---
   824‚Üí
   825‚Üí## Mint and Burn (Outcome Feedback)
   826‚Üí
   827‚Üí### When to Mint (Reward Usefulness)
   828‚Üí
   829‚Üí**Trigger conditions (learned detectors, no timers):**
   830‚Üí
   831‚Üí1. **Propensity-weighted advantage > 0** - Source improved outcomes
   832‚Üí   ```python
   833‚Üí   advantage = compute_propensity_weighted_advantage(source, action, outcome, state)
   834‚Üí   if advantage > 0:
   835‚Üí       mint_amount = base_mint * advantage * cap_by_variance()
   836‚Üí       mint_to_account(source)
   837‚Üí   ```
   838‚Üí
   839‚Üí2. **TRACE success** - Formation becomes integrated and retrieved
   840‚Üí   ```python
   841‚Üí   if formation_integrated and retrieval_count > learned_threshold():
   842‚Üí       mint_amount = base_mint * formation_quality * retrieval_score
   843‚Üí       mint_to_account(formation.source)
   844‚Üí   ```
   845‚Üí
   846‚Üí3. **System health improvement** - œÅ drops after stimulus
   847‚Üí   ```python
   848‚Üí   if detect_rho_drop_after_stimulus(stimulus_id):
   849‚Üí       mint_amount = base_mint * abs(delta_rho) * cap_by_variance()
   850‚Üí       mint_to_account(stimulus.source)
   851‚Üí   ```
   852‚Üí
   853‚Üí**Mint amounts (learned, bounded):**
   854‚Üí- `base_mint` starts at 10 credits per positive outcome
   855‚Üí- Capped by learned EMAs of variance (prevents boom/bust)
   856‚Üí- Credits are **internal allowances** (offset future charges), not cash-out
   857‚Üí
   858‚Üí---
   859‚Üí
   860‚Üí### When to Burn (Penalize Harm)
   861‚Üí
   862‚Üí**Trigger conditions:**
   863‚Üí
   864‚Üí1. **Harm signal rise** - Energy flow increases harm_ema
   865‚Üí   ```python
   866‚Üí   if harm_ema_increased_after_stimulus(stimulus_id):
   867‚Üí       burn_amount = base_burn * harm_delta
   868‚Üí       burn_from_account(stimulus.source)
   869‚Üí   ```
   870‚Üí
   871‚Üí2. **Execution failure** - Triggered action fails
   872‚Üí   ```python
   873‚Üí   if action_failed and caused_by_stimulus(action, stimulus_id):
   874‚Üí       burn_amount = base_burn * failure_severity
   875‚Üí       burn_from_account(stimulus.source)
   876‚Üí   ```
   877‚Üí
   878‚Üí3. **Guardian veto** - Safety system blocks action
   879‚Üí   ```python
   880‚Üí   if guardian_blocked(action) and linked_to_stimulus(action, stimulus_id):
   881‚Üí       burn_amount = base_burn * veto_strength
   882‚Üí       burn_from_account(stimulus.source)
   883‚Üí   ```
   884‚Üí
   885‚Üí**Burn amounts (learned):**
   886‚Üí- `base_burn` starts at 5 credits per negative outcome (smaller than mint to avoid over-punishment)
   887‚Üí- Adjusted based on "how much burn deters harmful sources without killing useful-but-risky exploration"
   888‚Üí
   889‚Üí---
   890‚Üí
   891‚Üí### Budget Replenishment
   892‚Üí
   893‚Üí**Trigger (not timer-based):**
   894‚Üí```python
   895‚Üíif account.balance < learned_low_threshold(account):
   896‚Üí    # Review recent utility
   897‚Üí    if account.utility_ema > learned_utility_floor():
   898‚Üí        # Useful source running dry ‚Üí replenish
   899‚Üí        replenish_amount = learned_baseline_allocation(account.owner_type) * 0.2
   900‚Üí        mint_to_account(account)
   901‚Üí        emit_telemetry("budget.replenished", {
   902‚Üí            "account": account.owner_id,
   903‚Üí            "amount": replenish_amount,
   904‚Üí            "reason": "useful_source_low_balance"
   905‚Üí        })
   906‚Üí```
   907‚Üí
   908‚Üí**Thresholds learned from:**
   909‚Üí- How often sources hit zero and stop participating
   910‚Üí- Balance between "keep useful sources active" and "enforce consequence for low utility"
   911‚Üí
   912‚Üí---
   913‚Üí
   914‚Üí## Citizen-to-Citizen Communication
   915‚Üí
   916‚Üí### Communication Model (Graph-Only)
   917‚Üí
   918‚Üí**When citizen A wants to message citizen B:**
   919‚Üí
   920‚Üí1. **Create stimulus** with channel `message` or `mission`
   921‚Üí   ```python
   922‚Üí   stimulus = {
   923‚Üí       "scope": "personal",  # Target B's L1 graph
   924‚Üí       "channel": "message",
   925‚Üí       "citizen_id": "felix",  # Sender
   926‚Üí       "target_citizen": "atlas",  # Receiver
   927‚Üí       "content": "Atlas, can you review the MembraneStore persistence?",
   928‚Üí       "features_raw": {
   929‚Üí           "novelty": 0.6,
   930‚Üí           "uncertainty": 0.3,
   931‚Üí           "trust": 0.9,  # A's trust in B
   932‚Üí           "urgency": 0.5,
   933‚Üí           "valence": 0.2,
   934‚Üí           "scale": 0.4
   935‚Üí       },
   936‚Üí       "provenance": {...}
   937‚Üí   }
   938‚Üí   ```
   939‚Üí
   940‚Üí2. **Price and budget check** (same as any stimulus)
   941‚Üí   - **Sender's account (felix) pays** for delivery
   942‚Üí   - Price = `P_t √ó ŒîE_delivered`
   943‚Üí
   944‚Üí3. **Route to receiver's graph** (atlas L1)
   945‚Üí   - Stimulus enters atlas's injection pipeline
   946‚Üí   - Integrator applies novelty, saturation, refractory
   947‚Üí   - Energy delivered to atlas's graph nodes
   948‚Üí
   949‚Üí4. **Receiver's energy field unchanged** - energy NOT subtracted from sender
   950‚Üí   - **Separation:** Sender pays credits (accounting), receiver gets energy (physics)
   951‚Üí   - Preserves single-energy locality (no coupling between sender and receiver fields)
   952‚Üí
   953‚Üí---
   954‚Üí
   955‚Üí### Anti-Spam for Communication
   956‚Üí
   957‚Üí**Repeated messages from A to B:**
   958‚Üí1. **Integrator saturation** - A's mass EMA for B's thread increases ‚Üí ŒîE per message shrinks
   959‚Üí2. **Refractory period** - Rapid sends hit learned cooldown ‚Üí ŒîE further reduced
   960‚Üí3. **Budget drain** - Under load, `P_t` rises ‚Üí A's budget depletes faster
   961‚Üí4. **Utility feedback** - If B never responds/acts on A's messages, A's utility_ema drops ‚Üí higher future prices
   962‚Üí
   963‚Üí**Result:** 20 rapid messages deliver ‚â§1.2√ó energy of single message (integrator physics) AND drain A's budget 20√ó faster (accounting consequence).
   964‚Üí
   965‚Üí---
   966‚Üí
   967‚Üí### Optional L2 Routing
   968‚Üí
   969‚Üí**For broadcast or coordination:**
   970‚Üí- A sends stimulus with `scope="organizational"` ‚Üí L2 graph
   971‚Üí- L2 processes, generates missions
   972‚Üí- L2 emits downward stimuli to multiple L1 citizens (via CrossLevelMembrane)
   973‚Üí- Each downward stimulus costs L2's budget (not A's directly)
   974‚Üí
   975‚Üí**Use cases:**
   976‚Üí- Broadcast announcements
   977‚Üí- Multi-citizen coordination
   978‚Üí- Mission assignment
   979‚Üí
   980‚Üí---
   981‚Üí
   982‚Üí## Integration with Existing Systems
   983‚Üí
   984‚Üí### Stimulus Integrator (Unchanged)
   985‚Üí
   986‚Üí**The existing `stimulus_integrator.py` needs NO changes to physics.**
   987‚Üí
   988‚Üí**What changes:**
   989‚Üí- **Input:** Receives `delta_e_allowed` (clamped by budget) instead of raw `delta_e_plan`
   990‚Üí- **Output:** Returns `delta_e_delivered` (after integrator mechanics)
   991‚Üí
   992‚Üí```python
   993‚Üí# Before economy:
   994‚Üídelta_e_delivered = integrator.inject(stimulus, stimulus["features_raw"]["novelty"])
   995‚Üí
   996‚Üí# After economy:
   997‚Üídelta_e_allowed = budget_check(stimulus, account)  # NEW: clamps based on budget
   998‚Üídelta_e_delivered = integrator.inject(stimulus, delta_e_allowed)  # SAME integrator
   999‚Üíaccount.balance -= price * delta_e_delivered  # NEW: debit account
  1000‚Üí```
  1001‚Üí
  1002‚Üí**Integrator still does:**
  1003‚Üí- Saturation: `œÉ(m) = log(1 + m)`
  1004‚Üí- Refractory: `R(rate, œÜ)`
  1005‚Üí- Trust/harm gate: `h(trust, uncertainty, harm_ema, guardian)`
  1006‚Üí- Dynamic decay: `œÑ(trust, uncertainty, novelty, retrieval_pressure)`
  1007‚Üí
  1008‚Üí**Budget only affects the magnitude passed in.**
  1009‚Üí
  1010‚Üí---
  1011‚Üí
  1012‚Üí### Cross-Level Membrane (Extended)
  1013‚Üí
  1014‚Üí**The `CrossLevelMembrane` already has permeability (k_up, k_down).**
  1015‚Üí
  1016‚Üí**Add budget integration:**
  1017‚Üí- When membrane emits upward stimulus (L1‚ÜíL2), **debit L1 compartment account**
  1018‚Üí- When membrane emits downward mission (L2‚ÜíL1), **debit L2 compartment account**
  1019‚Üí
  1020‚Üí```python
  1021‚Üí# In CrossLevelMembrane.try_emit_upward():
  1022‚Üíenvelope = self._build_l2_envelope(...)
  1023‚Üí
  1024‚Üí# NEW: Check L1 citizen's compartment budget
  1025‚Üíaccount = get_compartment_account(citizen, level="L1")
  1026‚Üídelta_e_allowed = budget_check_for_transfer(account, envelope)
  1027‚Üí
  1028‚Üíif delta_e_allowed > 0:
  1029‚Üí    self.injector.post(envelope)  # Existing
  1030‚Üí    account.balance -= price * delta_e_allowed  # NEW
  1031‚Üí```
  1032‚Üí
  1033‚Üí**Why compartment budgets:**
  1034‚Üí- L1 citizen compartment has reserve for upward transfers
  1035‚Üí- L2 org compartment has reserve for downward missions
  1036‚Üí- Prevents infinite upward spam (budget limits total flow)
  1037‚Üí
  1038‚Üí---
  1039‚Üí
  1040‚Üí### L2 Stimulus Collector (Extended)
  1041‚Üí
  1042‚Üí**The `L2StimulusCollector` creates envelopes from citizen activity.**
  1043‚Üí
  1044‚Üí**Add budget integration:**
  1045‚Üí- When collector creates L2 stimulus, **debit citizen's account** (not compartment)
  1046‚Üí- Citizen pays for the L2 attention their activity requests
  1047‚Üí
  1048‚Üí```python
  1049‚Üí# In L2StimulusCollector.on_file_created():
  1050‚Üíenvelope = self._build_file_op_envelope(...)
  1051‚Üí
  1052‚Üí# NEW: Check citizen's budget
  1053‚Üíaccount = get_account(citizen, owner_type="citizen")
  1054‚Üídelta_e_allowed = budget_check(envelope, account)
  1055‚Üí
  1056‚Üíif delta_e_allowed > 0:
  1057‚Üí    self.injector.post(envelope)  # Existing
  1058‚Üí    account.balance -= price * delta_e_allowed  # NEW
  1059‚Üí```
  1060‚Üí
  1061‚Üí**Why citizen accounts:**
  1062‚Üí- Citizen's work creates L2 stimuli
  1063‚Üí- Citizen should have budget to support their activity
  1064‚Üí- Prevents runaway file change floods (budget limits)

  1164‚Üí## Acceptance Criteria
  1165‚Üí
  1166‚Üí### 1. Load-Based Pricing
  1167‚Üí
  1168‚Üí**Given:** System idle (œÅ=0.3, backlog=0)
  1169‚Üí**When:** 10 stimuli injected
  1170‚Üí**Then:** All pay `P_t ‚âà 1.0` (base price, no scarcity)
  1171‚Üí
  1172‚Üí**Given:** Load spike (œÅ‚Üí0.9, backlog‚Üí100)
  1173‚Üí**When:** 10 stimuli injected
  1174‚Üí**Then:** Price rises to `P_t ‚âà 8.0` (8√ó base), total ŒîE_delivered drops smoothly
  1175‚Üí
  1176‚Üí---
  1177‚Üí
  1178‚Üí### 2. Spam Self-Throttling
  1179‚Üí
  1180‚Üí**Given:** Malicious source sends 20 back-to-back messages
  1181‚Üí**When:** Budget balance < cost of 5 messages
  1182‚Üí**Then:** First 5 deliver full ŒîE, remaining 15 deliver 0 ŒîE (budget exhausted)
  1183‚Üí
  1184‚Üí**Given:** Same spam with full budget
  1185‚Üí**When:** Integrator saturation + refractory active
  1186‚Üí**Then:** Total ŒîE ‚â§ 1.2√ó single message (physics) + budget drains 20√ó faster (accounting)
  1187‚Üí
  1188‚Üí---
  1189‚Üí
  1190‚Üí### 3. Utility Rebates
  1191‚Üí
  1192‚Üí**Given:** Felix has utility_ema = 0.9 (high value)
  1193‚Üí**When:** Stimulus injected during moderate load
  1194‚Üí**Then:** Price multiplier includes `f_utility ‚âà 0.65` (35% discount)
  1195‚Üí
  1196‚Üí**Given:** Unknown source with utility_ema = 0.1 (low value)
  1197‚Üí**When:** Same load conditions
  1198‚Üí**Then:** Price multiplier includes `f_utility ‚âà 1.85` (85% surcharge)
  1199‚Üí
  1200‚Üí---
  1201‚Üí
  1202‚Üí### 4. Citizen Communication Costs
  1203‚Üí
  1204‚Üí**Given:** Felix sends message to Atlas
  1205‚Üí**When:** Delivery happens
  1206‚Üí**Then:** Felix's balance decreases by `P_t √ó ŒîE_delivered`, Atlas's graph receives energy (no energy subtracted from Felix's field)
  1207‚Üí
  1208‚Üí---
  1209‚Üí
  1210‚Üí### 5. Mint on Success
  1211‚Üí
  1212‚Üí**Given:** Atlas completes task successfully
  1213‚Üí**When:** Outcome detected
  1214‚Üí**Then:** Atlas's balance increases by learned mint amount (‚â•10 credits)
  1215‚Üí
  1216‚Üí---
  1217‚Üí
  1218‚Üí### 6. Burn on Harm
  1219‚Üí
  1220‚Üí**Given:** Stimulus causes harm_ema to rise
  1221‚Üí**When:** Harm detected
  1222‚Üí**Then:** Source's balance decreases by learned burn amount (‚â•5 credits)
  1223‚Üí
  1224‚Üí---
  1225‚Üí
  1226‚Üí### 7. Budget Replenishment
  1227‚Üí
  1228‚Üí**Given:** Felix's balance drops below learned threshold
  1229‚Üí**When:** Felix's utility_ema > learned floor
  1230‚Üí**Then:** Replenishment mint triggered, balance increases by 20% of baseline
  1231‚Üí
  1232‚Üí---
  1233‚Üí
  1234‚Üí### 8. Compute Cost Alignment
  1235‚Üí
  1236‚Üí**Given:** Stimulus predicted to use 5000 tokens + 10 tools
  1237‚Üí**When:** Price computed
  1238‚Üí**Then:** `f_cost ‚âà 4.5` (4.5√ó base price for high compute)
  1239‚Üí
  1240‚Üí**Given:** Actual execution uses 6000 tokens
  1241‚Üí**When:** Settlement occurs
  1242‚Üí**Then:** Additional cost debited from account (settle actual vs predicted)
  1243‚Üí

1‚Üí# L2 Stimulus Collector Specification
     2‚Üí

     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## Purpose
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí**The L2 Stimulus Collector captures citizen activity and converts it into L2 stimuli.**
    13‚Üí
    14‚ÜíThis enables upward flow (L1‚ÜíL2): when citizens work, learn, create, and respond, those activities become stimuli for the organizational consciousness to process.
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí**What gets collected:**
    17‚Üí1. **File operations** - Code/doc creates, edits, deletes
    18‚Üí2. **TRACE formations** - New nodes and links from citizen responses
    19‚Üí3. **Git operations** - Commits, branches, merges
    20‚Üí4. **Conversation responses** - Completed citizen responses to humans/citizens
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí**Architecture principle:** Stimulus Collector feeds the normal injection pipeline. It doesn't bypass energy mechanics - it creates canonical stimulus envelopes that flow through Stimulus Integrator like any other stimulus.
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí---
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí## Why This Matters
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí**Without L2 Stimulus Collector:**
    29‚Üí- L2 remains blind to citizen activity
    30‚Üí- Upward membrane has no events to evaluate
    31‚Üí- Organization can't learn from individual work
    32‚Üí- Cross-level consciousness is one-way (L2‚ÜíL1 only)
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí**With L2 Stimulus Collector:**
    35‚Üí- Every citizen action becomes potential L2 stimulus
    36‚Üí- Spam resistance via Stimulus Integrator mechanics (saturation, trust, novelty)
    37‚Üí- Membrane evaluates significance and emits only record events
    38‚Üí- Organization learns from emergent patterns across citizens
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí---
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí## Architecture Overview
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí```
    45‚ÜíCitizen Activity Sources:
    46‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ File Watcher (creates/edits/deletes)
    47‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ TRACE Parser (formations from responses)
    48‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Git Hook (commits/branches)
    49‚Üí  ‚îî‚îÄ Response Completer (conversation turns)
    50‚Üí          ‚Üì
    51‚ÜíL2StimulusCollector (THIS SPEC)
    52‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Extract semantic signals
    53‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Build canonical envelope
    54‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Enrich with provenance
    55‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Apply learned pre-filters (NOT spam gates - those are in Integrator)
    56‚Üí          ‚Üì
    57‚ÜíStimulus Injection Service
    58‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Routes to scope=organizational (L2 graph)
    59‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Stimulus Integrator (saturation, trust, harm gating)
    60‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Energy injection ‚Üí L2 nodes
    61‚Üí          ‚Üì
    62‚ÜíCrossLevelMembrane
    63‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Evaluates L2 node flips
    64‚Üí  ‚îú‚îÄ Record events ‚Üí Emit upward stimulus
    65‚Üí```
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí**Key insight:** L2StimulusCollector creates envelopes. Spam resistance happens in Stimulus Integrator. Significance filtering happens in Membrane. Clean separation of concerns.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí---
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí## Event Sources
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### 1. File Operations
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**What to capture:**
    76‚Üí- File creates (new scripts, specs, components)
    77‚Üí- File edits (code changes, spec updates)
    78‚Üí- File deletes (cleanup, deprecation)
    79‚Üí- File renames/moves
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí**How to capture:**
    82‚Üí- Existing `conversation_watcher.py` pattern (file system watching)
    83‚Üí- Watch paths: `orchestration/**/*.py`, `app/**/*.tsx`, `docs/specs/**/*.md`
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí**Signal extraction:**
    86‚Üí```python
    87‚Üídef extract_file_op_signals(event: FileSystemEvent) -> Dict:
    88‚Üí    """
    89‚Üí    Extract semantic signals from file operation.
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí    Returns canonical features for stimulus envelope.
    92‚Üí    """
    93‚Üí    # Determine file importance (not arbitrary - learned from retrieval patterns)
    94‚Üí    importance = estimate_file_importance(event.src_path)
    95‚Üí
    96‚Üí    # Detect change magnitude (AST diff for code, text diff for docs)
    97‚Üí    magnitude = compute_change_magnitude(event)
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí    # Extract citizen who made change (from file path pattern)
   100‚Üí    citizen = extract_citizen_from_path(event.src_path)
   101‚Üí
   102‚Üí    # Detect change type
   103‚Üí    change_type = classify_change(event)  # feature_add, bug_fix, refactor, docs, etc.
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí    return {
   106‚Üí        "novelty": magnitude * importance,  # Big changes to important files = high novelty
   107‚Üí        "uncertainty": estimate_uncertainty(change_type),  # Refactors more uncertain than docs
   108‚Üí        "trust": get_citizen_trust(citizen),  # From historical success rates
   109‚Üí        "urgency": detect_urgency(event),  # "CRITICAL" in commit msg, test failures, etc.
   110‚Üí        "valence": 0.0,  # Neutral for file ops (sentiment comes from TRACE)
   111‚Üí        "scale": importance  # How central is this file to architecture
   112‚Üí    }
   113‚Üí```
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí**Envelope template:**
   116‚Üí```json
   117‚Üí{
   118‚Üí  "scope": "organizational",
   119‚Üí  "channel": "citizen_file_ops",

   121‚Üí  "content": "Felix created orchestration/mechanisms/cross_level_membrane.py implementing L1‚ÜîL2 stimulus emission with learned permeability",
   122‚Üí  "features_raw": {
   123‚Üí    "novelty": 0.85,
   124‚Üí    "uncertainty": 0.40,
   125‚Üí    "trust": 0.90,
   126‚Üí    "urgency": 0.50,
   127‚Üí    "valence": 0.0,
   128‚Üí    "scale": 0.80
   129‚Üí  },
   130‚Üí  "provenance": {
   131‚Üí    "source_type": "file_operation",

   143‚Üí
   144‚Üí### 2. TRACE Formations
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí**What to capture:**
   147‚Üí- NODE_FORMATION blocks from citizen responses
   148‚Üí- LINK_FORMATION blocks from citizen responses
   149‚Üí- Node reinforcement signals (useful/misleading markers)
   150‚Üí
   151‚Üí**How to capture:**
   152‚Üí- Parse conversation JSON after citizen completes response
   153‚Üí- Extract formation blocks using existing trace_parser.py patterns
   154‚Üí
   155‚Üí**Signal extraction:**
   156‚Üí```python
   157‚Üídef extract_trace_signals(formations: List[Dict]) -> Dict:
   158‚Üí    """
   159‚Üí    Extract semantic signals from TRACE formations.
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí    Formations indicate citizen learning - high organizational value.
   162‚Üí    """
   163‚Üí    # Count formations by type
   164‚Üí    node_count = len([f for f in formations if f["type"] == "NODE_FORMATION"])
   165‚Üí    link_count = len([f for f in formations if f["type"] == "LINK_FORMATION"])
   166‚Üí
   167‚Üí    # Average confidence across formations
   168‚Üí    avg_confidence = np.mean([f.get("confidence", 0.5) for f in formations])
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí    # Detect formation triggers (spontaneous_insight > inference > systematic_analysis)
   171‚Üí    triggers = [f.get("formation_trigger") for f in formations]
   172‚Üí    insight_ratio = triggers.count("spontaneous_insight") / len(triggers)
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí    # Detect scope (organizational formations more relevant to L2)
   175‚Üí    org_ratio = sum(1 for f in formations if f.get("scope") == "organizational") / len(formations)
   176‚Üí
   177‚Üí    return {
   178‚Üí        "novelty": 0.3 + 0.7 * insight_ratio,  # Insights = high novelty
   179‚Üí        "uncertainty": 1.0 - avg_confidence,  # Low confidence = high uncertainty
   180‚Üí        "trust": avg_confidence,  # High confidence formations = trustworthy
   181‚Üí        "urgency": 0.3 + 0.7 * org_ratio,  # Org-scoped formations urgent for L2
   182‚Üí        "valence": 0.5,  # Learning is positive
   183‚Üí        "scale": min(1.0, (node_count + link_count) / 5.0)  # More formations = larger scale
   184‚Üí    }
   185‚Üí```
   186‚Üí

   217‚Üí### 3. Git Operations
   218‚Üí
   219‚Üí**What to capture:**
   220‚Üí- Commits (with messages, files changed, LOC delta)
   221‚Üí- Branch creates (feature branches signal new work streams)
   222‚Üí- Merges (integration points signal completion)
   223‚Üí
   224‚Üí**How to capture:**
   225‚Üí- Git hooks (post-commit, post-merge)
   226‚Üí- Or periodic git log polling
   227‚Üí
   228‚Üí**Signal extraction:**
   229‚Üí```python
   230‚Üídef extract_git_signals(commit: Dict) -> Dict:
   231‚Üí    """
   232‚Üí    Extract semantic signals from git commit.
   233‚Üí    """
   234‚Üí    # Parse commit message for intent
   235‚Üí    intent = classify_commit_intent(commit["message"])  # feat/fix/refactor/docs/test
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí    # Measure impact (files changed, LOC delta)
   238‚Üí    impact = compute_commit_impact(commit["files"], commit["additions"], commit["deletions"])
   239‚Üí
   240‚Üí    # Detect urgency from message
   241‚Üí    urgency = detect_urgency_keywords(commit["message"])  # CRITICAL, URGENT, HOTFIX, etc.
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí    # Extract citizen from author
   244‚Üí    citizen = extract_citizen_from_author(commit["author"])
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí    return {
   247‚Üí        "novelty": impact * intent_novelty[intent],  # Big feature adds = high novelty
   248‚Üí        "uncertainty": intent_uncertainty[intent],  # Refactors more uncertain
   249‚Üí        "trust": get_citizen_trust(citizen),
   250‚Üí        "urgency": urgency,
   251‚Üí        "valence": intent_valence[intent],  # Fixes positive, breaking changes negative
   252‚Üí        "scale": impact
   253‚Üí    }
   254‚Üí```
   255‚Üí

   287‚Üí### 4. Conversation Responses
   288‚Üí
   289‚Üí**What to capture:**
   290‚Üí- Completed citizen responses (not every token, only full turns)
   291‚Üí- Response metadata (length, subentity activations, energy level)
   292‚Üí
   293‚Üí**How to capture:**
   294‚Üí- Hook into conversation completion in ws_api
   295‚Üí- Extract after citizen finishes responding
   296‚Üí
   297‚Üí**Signal extraction:**
   298‚Üí```python
   299‚Üídef extract_response_signals(response: Dict) -> Dict:
   300‚Üí    """
   301‚Üí    Extract semantic signals from citizen response completion.
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí    Response quality indicates citizen effectiveness.
   304‚Üí    """
   305‚Üí    # Measure response depth (length, formation count)
   306‚Üí    depth = compute_response_depth(response)
   307‚Üí
   308‚Üí    # Detect subentity activation (which parts of consciousness engaged)
   309‚Üí    activation_breadth = len(response.get("active_subentities", []))
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí    # Extract energy level (Peak > Energized > Engaged > Focused > Alert)
   312‚Üí    energy = parse_energy_level(response)
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí    # Detect if response shows uncertainty/questions
   315‚Üí    uncertainty = detect_uncertainty_markers(response["content"])
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí    # Extract citizen
   318‚Üí    citizen = response["citizen_id"]
   319‚Üí
   320‚Üí    return {
   321‚Üí        "novelty": depth * 0.5 + activation_breadth * 0.3,
   322‚Üí        "uncertainty": uncertainty,
   323‚Üí        "trust": get_citizen_trust(citizen),
   324‚Üí        "urgency": energy / 10.0,  # Peak=1.0, Dormant=0.0
   325‚Üí        "valence": parse_sentiment(response["content"]),
   326‚Üí        "scale": depth
   327‚Üí    }
   328‚Üí```
