   329‚Üí- **Bulk operations** - 100 items, not custom artisan content
   330‚Üí- **Client provides examples** - "Make it like this"
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí**Mission Types We Should Hunt:**
   333‚Üí
   334‚Üí**5. Product Description Generation**
   335‚Üí```
   336‚ÜíExample: "Generate 500 product descriptions from spec sheets"
   337‚Üí
   338‚ÜíAC.md (the key is TEMPLATE):
   339‚Üí- Input: CSV with {name, features, specs, price}
   340‚Üí- Template: [Client provides 5 example descriptions]
   341‚Üí- Tone: Professional, benefit-focused
   342‚Üí- Length: 100-150 words each
   343‚Üí- Output: CSV with generated descriptions
   344‚Üí- Quality gate: Client approves 10 random samples before bulk
   345‚Üí
   346‚ÜíBudget: $400-800
   347‚ÜíTime: 6-10 hours (mostly setup + testing)
   348‚ÜíStack: Python + Claude API + CSV processing
   349‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$20-40 (500 generations)
   350‚Üí```
   351‚Üí
   352‚Üí**6. Blog Post Outlines from Keywords**
   353‚Üí```
   354‚ÜíExample: "Generate 200 SEO blog outlines for SaaS topics"
   355‚Üí
   356‚ÜíAC.md:
   357‚Üí- Input: Keywords list
   358‚Üí- Output format: {title, H2s, H3s, key_points[]}
   359‚Üí- Structure: Intro, 3-5 sections, conclusion, CTA
   360‚Üí- Template: [Client provides 3 examples]
   361‚Üí- SEO: Include keyword in title + 2 H2s
   362‚Üí- Quality: Client approves 20 samples
   363‚Üí
   364‚ÜíBudget: $350-600
   365‚ÜíTime: 6-8 hours
   366‚ÜíStack: Python + Claude API
   367‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$15-30
   368‚Üí```
   369‚Üí
   370‚Üí**7. Email Template Personalization**
   371‚Üí```
   372‚ÜíExample: "Personalize 1000 outreach emails from prospect data"
   373‚Üí
   374‚ÜíAC.md:
   375‚Üí- Input: CSV with {name, company, industry, pain_point}
   376‚Üí- Template: [Client provides base email]
   377‚Üí- Personalize: Greeting, problem statement, CTA
   378‚Üí- Constraints: <200 words, professional tone
   379‚Üí- Output: 1000 unique emails
   380‚Üí- Quality: No repeated phrases across emails
   381‚Üí
   382‚ÜíBudget: $300-500
   383‚ÜíTime: 4-8 hours
   384‚ÜíStack: Python + Claude API + CSV
   385‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$10-25
   386‚Üí```
   387‚Üí
   388‚Üí---
   389‚Üí
   390‚Üí### Tier 3: Image Generation/Processing (PROCEED WITH CAUTION)
   391‚Üí
   392‚Üí**Why These Are Tricky:**
   393‚Üí- ‚ö†Ô∏è Subjective quality ("I don't like the style")
   394‚Üí- ‚ö†Ô∏è High API costs ($0.02-0.10 per image)
   395‚Üí- ‚ö†Ô∏è Iteration risk (endless "make it better")
   396‚Üí
   397‚Üí**When to Say Yes:**
   398‚Üí
   399‚ÜíOnly if client provides:
   400‚Üí1. Exact style reference images
   401‚Üí2. Specific dimensions/format requirements
   402‚Üí3. Test batch approval before bulk generation
   403‚Üí4. Fixed revision rounds (1-2 max)
   404‚Üí
   405‚Üí**8. Automated Background Removal (SAFE)**
   406‚Üí```
   407‚ÜíExample: "Remove background from 500 product photos"
   408‚Üí
   409‚ÜíAC.md (this one is OBJECTIVE):
   410‚Üí- Input: 500 JPGs
   411‚Üí- Process: Remove background ‚Üí transparent PNG
   412‚Üí- Quality: No artifacts on edges (visual inspection on 10 samples)
   413‚Üí- Output: 500 PNGs, same dimensions
   414‚Üí- Speed: Batch process, <5min total
   415‚Üí
   416‚ÜíBudget: $250-400
   417‚ÜíTime: 3-6 hours (mostly setup)
   418‚ÜíStack: Python + remove.bg API or rembg library
   419‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$50-100 (remove.bg) OR $0 (local rembg)
   420‚Üí
   421‚ÜíWHY THIS WORKS: Objective success criteria (background gone or not)
   422‚Üí```
   423‚Üí
   424‚Üí**9. Bulk Social Media Graphics (RISKY BUT POSSIBLE)**
   425‚Üí```
   426‚ÜíExample: "Generate 100 Instagram posts for motivational quotes"
   427‚Üí
   428‚ÜíAC.md (KEY: Strict template):
   429‚Üí- Input: CSV with {quote, author}
   430‚Üí- Template: [Client provides 3 approved designs]
   431‚Üí- Dimensions: 1080x1080px
   432‚Üí- Format: PNG
   433‚Üí- Consistency: Use exact same layout/fonts/colors
   434‚Üí- Client approves: 5 samples before bulk generation
   435‚Üí
   436‚ÜíBudget: $400-700
   437‚ÜíTime: 8-12 hours (template setup + generation)
   438‚ÜíStack: Python + Pillow/Canva API + template system
   439‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$0-20 (if using Canva API)
   440‚Üí
   441‚ÜíWHY RISKY: "I don't like the font" ‚Üí endless revisions
   442‚ÜíHOW TO MITIGATE: Client MUST approve template upfront
   443‚Üí```
   444‚Üí
   445‚Üí**10. AI Image Generation (HIGHEST RISK)**
   446‚Üí```
   447‚ÜíExample: "Generate 50 unique illustrations for blog posts"
   448‚Üí
   449‚ÜíRED FLAGS:
   450‚Üí‚ùå "Make them beautiful" (subjective)
   451‚Üí‚ùå "Match our brand style" (vague)
   452‚Üí‚ùå No reference images provided
   453‚Üí‚ùå Open-ended revisions
   454‚Üí
   455‚ÜíONLY SAY YES IF:
   456‚Üí‚úÖ Client provides 5+ reference images ("like this")
   457‚Üí‚úÖ Fixed style (e.g., "flat illustration, blue/orange palette")
   458‚Üí‚úÖ Test batch: Generate 5, client approves before bulk
   459‚Üí‚úÖ Max 1 revision round per image
   460‚Üí‚úÖ Budget accounts for API costs + revisions
   461‚Üí
   462‚ÜíBudget: $600-1000 (higher due to revision risk)
   463‚ÜíTime: 10-16 hours
   464‚ÜíStack: Python + DALL-E/Midjourney API
   465‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$50-150 (depending on model + revisions)
   466‚Üí```
   467‚Üí
   468‚Üí---
   469‚Üí
   470‚Üí### Tier 4: AI-Powered Features (ADVANCED - Week 4+)
   471‚Üí
   472‚Üí**11. Chatbot Integration**
   473‚Üí```
   474‚ÜíExample: "Add AI chatbot to website for customer support"
   475‚Üí
   476‚ÜíBudget: $600-1200
   477‚ÜíTime: 12-20 hours
   478‚ÜíStack: Next.js + OpenAI API + vector DB (Pinecone)
   479‚ÜíAPI Cost: ~$10-30/month ongoing
   480‚Üí```
   481‚Üí
   482‚Üí**12. Recommendation Engines**
   483‚Üí```
   484‚ÜíExample: "Build product recommendation system based on user behavior"
   485‚Üí
   486‚ÜíBudget: $800-1500
   487‚ÜíTime: 20-30 hours
   488‚ÜíStack: Python + embeddings + similarity search
   489‚Üí```
   490‚Üí
   491‚Üí---
   492‚Üí
   493‚Üí## Auto-Pass Categories
   494‚Üí
   495‚Üí**Never bid on these (Week 1-8):**
   496‚Üí
   497‚Üí‚ùå **Mobile Apps**
   498‚Üí- React Native, Flutter, Swift, Kotlin
   499‚Üí- Why: Outside stack, different testing requirements
   500‚Üí
   501‚Üí‚ùå **Machine Learning / Data Science**
   502‚Üí- "Train a model," "Predict X," "Analyze dataset"
   503‚Üí- Why: Requires specialized skills AI can't fully generate
   504‚Üí
   505‚Üí‚ùå **Game Development**
   506‚Üí- Unity, Unreal, Godot
   507‚Üí- Why: Complex physics/rendering, high bug risk
   508‚Üí
   509‚Üí‚ùå **Legacy Code Modernization**
   510‚Üí- "Rewrite old PHP site to React"
   511‚Üí- Why: Hidden complexity, scope creep guaranteed
   512‚Üí
   513‚Üí‚ùå **"Ongoing" or "Maintenance" Without Clear Deliverables**
   514‚Üí- "Help maintain our codebase"
   515‚Üí- Why: Never done, scope creep
   516‚Üí
   517‚Üí‚ùå **SEO / Marketing / Content**
   518‚Üí- "Optimize our site for Google"
   519‚Üí- Why: Not development work
   520‚Üí
   521‚Üí‚ùå **Complex Algorithms**
   522‚Üí- "Implement custom encryption"
   523‚Üí- Why: High risk of bugs, hard to test
   524‚Üí

   527‚Üí## Decision Flowchart
   528‚Üí
   529‚Üí```

   531‚Üí    ‚Üì
   532‚ÜíBudget $200-600? ‚Üí NO ‚Üí Pass
   533‚Üí    ‚Üì YES

   537‚Üí    ‚Üì YES

   548‚Üí

   551‚Üí## Updated Decision Criteria
   552‚Üí
   553‚Üí### Add These Green Flags
   554‚Üí
   555‚Üí**For Document/Data Processing:**
   556‚Üí- ‚úÖ Client has sample data (test set)
   557‚Üí- ‚úÖ Clear fields to extract (not "get all useful info")
   558‚Üí- ‚úÖ Measurable accuracy (95%+ on test set)
   559‚Üí- ‚úÖ Client can verify output objectively
   560‚Üí
   561‚Üí**For Content Generation:**
   562‚Üí- ‚úÖ Template provided by client
   563‚Üí- ‚úÖ Bulk operation (50+ items, not custom)
   564‚Üí- ‚úÖ Approval gate (5-10 samples before bulk)
   565‚Üí- ‚úÖ Fixed format (not "be creative")
   566‚Üí
   567‚Üí**For Image Tasks:**
   568‚Üí- ‚úÖ Objective criteria (dimensions, format, specific style)
   569‚Üí- ‚úÖ Reference images provided
   570‚Üí- ‚úÖ Test batch approval built into timeline
   571‚Üí- ‚úÖ Fixed revision rounds (1-2 max)
   572‚Üí
   573‚Üí### Add These Red Flags
   574‚Üí
   575‚Üí**For ANY AI Integration:**
   576‚Üí- ‚ùå "Make it perfect" (subjective)
   577‚Üí- ‚ùå "Be creative" without constraints
   578‚Üí- ‚ùå No test data provided
   579‚Üí- ‚ùå Unlimited revisions expected
   580‚Üí- ‚ùå "I'll know it when I see it"
   581‚Üí
   582‚Üí---
   583‚Üí
   584‚Üí## Pricing Strategy for AI Missions
   585‚Üí
   586‚Üí**Formula:**
   587‚Üí```
   588‚ÜíBase Dev Time √ó Hourly Rate + API Cost √ó 3 + Revision Buffer
   589‚Üí
   590‚ÜíExample:
   591‚Üí- Dev time: 8 hours √ó $50/hr = $400
   592‚Üí- API cost: $20 √ó 3 = $60 (buffer for errors/testing)
   593‚Üí- Revision buffer: $100 (for 1 round of fixes)
   594‚ÜíTotal: $560 ‚Üí Round to $600
   595‚Üí```
   596‚Üí
   597‚Üí**Why 3x API cost:**
   598‚Üí- 1x for production
   599‚Üí- 1x for testing
   600‚Üí- 1x for mistakes/revisions
   601‚Üí

   603‚Üí

   605‚Üí

   611‚Üí- Proposals: 5-10

   614‚Üí**Goal:** Land 1-2 of these by Friday.
   615‚Üí
   616‚Üí---
   617‚Üí
   618‚Üí## Emma's Evaluation Script
   619‚Üí
   620‚ÜíWhen Emma sees a job, she scores it:
   621‚Üí
   622‚Üí```
   623‚ÜíStack Match: 0-3 points (3 = 100% match)
   624‚ÜíBudget Fit: 0-2 points (2 = $200-600)
   625‚ÜíClear Scope: 0-2 points (2 = can write AC.md instantly)
   626‚ÜíClient Quality: 0-2 points (2 = 4+ green flags)
   627‚ÜíTimeline: 0-1 point (1 = 2-7 days)
   628‚ÜíAI Integration Fit: 0-3 points (3 = Perfect, 2 = Good, 1 = Risky, 0 = No AI)
   629‚Üí
   630‚ÜíTotal: 0-13 points
   631‚Üí
   632‚ÜíScore:
   633‚Üí- 8-13: Strong yes, write proposal
   634‚Üí- 6-7: Maybe, ask NLR
   635‚Üí- 0-5: Pass
   636‚Üí```
   637‚Üí
   638‚Üí---
   639‚Üí
   640‚Üí## Mission Target Summary Table
   641‚Üí
   642‚Üí| Type | Budget | Time | API Cost | Competition | Priority |
   643‚Üí|------|--------|------|----------|-------------|----------|
   644‚Üí| **PDF Parsing** | $400-800 | 6-12h | $5-15 | Low | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   645‚Üí| **Email Processing** | $350-600 | 8-14h | $2-8 | Low | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   646‚Üí| **Data Extraction** | $300-600 | 6-10h | $10-20 | Medium | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   647‚Üí| **Doc Classification** | $400-700 | 8-12h | $15-30 | Low | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   648‚Üí| **Product Descriptions** | $400-800 | 6-10h | $20-40 | Medium | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   649‚Üí| **Blog Outlines** | $350-600 | 6-8h | $15-30 | Medium | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   650‚Üí| **Email Personalization** | $300-500 | 4-8h | $10-25 | High | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   651‚Üí| **Background Removal** | $250-400 | 3-6h | $0-100 | Medium | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   652‚Üí| **Social Graphics** | $400-700 | 8-12h | $0-20 | Medium | ‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   653‚Üí| **AI Image Gen** | $600-1000 | 10-16h | $50-150 | High | ‚≠ê |
   654‚Üí| Landing Pages | $200-400 | 6-8h | $0 | High | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   655‚Üí| Telegram Bots | $200-400 | 4-6h | $0 | Low | ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê |
   656‚Üí
   657‚Üí---
   658‚Üí
   659‚Üí## Week 1 Revised Target Mix
   660‚Üí
   661‚Üí**Ideal portfolio:**
   662‚Üí- 1x Telegram bot ($250) - Fast cash, proven
   663‚Üí- 1x PDF parsing ($500) - Higher value, AI integration proof
   664‚Üí- 1x Landing page ($300) - Fallback if above don't land
   665‚Üí
   666‚Üí**Total: $1050 in pipeline, expect to land 1-2 = $250-800 Week 1 revenue**
   667‚Üí
   668‚Üí---
   669‚Üí
   670‚Üí## Real Examples (What to Look For)
   671‚Üí
   672‚Üí### ‚úÖ PERFECT JOB
   673‚Üí```
   674‚ÜíTitle: Build Landing Page for SaaS Product
   675‚ÜíBudget: $350
   676‚ÜíDescription:
   677‚Üí- Single page website
   678‚Üí- Hero section with CTA
   679‚Üí- Features grid (4 items)
   680‚Üí- Pricing table
   681‚Üí- Contact form (EmailJS)
   682‚Üí- Deploy to Vercel
   683‚Üí- Design: Clean, modern (provide Figma)
   684‚Üí- Timeline: 3 days
   685‚Üí
   686‚ÜíClient: $5K spent, 12 hires, 4.9 rating, payment verified
   687‚ÜíProposals: 8
   688‚Üí
   689‚ÜíWhy perfect:
   690‚Üí‚úÖ $350 = sweet spot
   691‚Üí‚úÖ 100% Next.js + Tailwind
   692‚Üí‚úÖ Clear deliverables (can write AC.md instantly)
   693‚Üí‚úÖ 3 days = fast cash
   694‚Üí‚úÖ Great client
   695‚Üí‚úÖ Low competition
   696‚Üí```
   697‚Üí
   698‚Üí### ‚ùå AVOID
   699‚Üí```
   700‚ÜíTitle: Help with our website
   701‚ÜíBudget: $500
   702‚ÜíDescription:
   703‚Üí- Make website faster
   704‚Üí- Improve design
   705‚Üí- Add some features
   706‚Üí- Ongoing help needed
   707‚Üí
   708‚ÜíClient: $0 spent, 0 hires, no payment verified
   709‚ÜíProposals: 23
   710‚Üí
   711‚ÜíWhy avoid:
   712‚Üí‚ùå Vague scope ("help," "improve," "some")
   713‚Üí‚ùå First-time client
   714‚Üí‚ùå High competition
   715‚Üí‚ùå "Ongoing" = never done
   716‚Üí```
   717‚Üí
   718‚Üí---
   719‚Üí
   720‚Üí## Strategy Progression
   721‚Üí
   722‚Üí**Week 1-2:** Focus on Web Dev + Document Processing (proven + easy AC.md)
   723‚Üí
   724‚Üí**Week 3-4:** Add Content Generation (once we've proven we can deliver)
   725‚Üí
   726‚Üí**Month 2+:** Carefully add Image tasks (highest risk, need track record first)
   727‚Üí
   728‚Üí---
   729‚Üí
   730‚Üí**This document is Emma's primary reference for evaluating which Upwork jobs to pursue. When in doubt, consult NLR.**
   731‚Üí

**Location:** `/home/mind-protocol/scopelock/citizens/emma/MISSION_SELECTION.md` ‚≠ê‚≠ê AUTHORITATIVE

## Quick Summary

**The Golden Rule:**
> We only take missions where AI can generate 80%+ of the code and humans just deploy/verify.

**6 Green Light Criteria (ALL must match):**
1. **Budget:** $200-$600 (Week 1-2), $600-$1500 (Week 3+)
2. **Stack Match:** 80%+ our tools (Python/JS/TS, Next.js, FastAPI, Postgres)
3. **Clear Deliverable:** Can write AC.md in 5 minutes
4. **Timeline:** 2-7 days
5. **Client Quality:** 3+ indicators (payment verified, $1000+ spent, 4.5+ rating)
6. **Competition:** <15 proposals

**Priority Mission Types (Week 1-2):**

**Tier 1 - AI Integration (HIGHEST PRIORITY):**
- PDF/Document Parsing: $400-800, 6-12h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Email Processing: $350-600, 8-14h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Telegram Bots: $200-400, 4-6h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

**Tier 2 - Web Development:**
- Landing Pages: $200-400, 6-8h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Simple APIs: $200-400, 4-6h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- CRUD Dashboards: $400-800, 12-20h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

**Week 1 Target Mix:**
- 1x Telegram bot ($250) - Fast cash
- 1x PDF parsing ($500) - AI integration proof
- 1x Landing page ($300) - Fallback

**Emma's Scoring System:**
- Stack match: 0-3 points
- Budget fit: 0-2 points
- Clear scope: 0-2 points
- Client quality: 0-2 points
- Timeline: 0-1 point
- AI integration fit: 0-3 points
- **Total:** 8-13 = strong yes, 6-7 = maybe, 0-5 = pass

**Auto-Pass Categories:**
- Mobile apps (React Native, Flutter)
- ML/Data Science
- Game development
- Legacy code modernization
- "Ongoing maintenance" without clear deliverables

---

1‚Üí# Upwork Project Catalog ‚Äì Complete Guide
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí**Version:** 1.0
     4‚Üí**Created:** 2025-11-03
     5‚Üí**Source:** Upwork Help Center
     6‚Üí**Purpose:** Reference for creating and managing ScopeLock projects in Upwork's Project Catalog
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí---
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## Overview
    11‚Üí
    12‚ÜíProject Catalog allows freelancers to create up to 20 unique projects (plus 20 more in review) with fixed-price packages that clients can purchase directly.
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí---
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí## How to Decide What Projects to Offer
    17‚Üí
    18‚Üí### Key Questions
    19‚Üí1. **What work have you enjoyed the most?**
    20‚Üí2. **What seems most in demand?** What do clients request most often?
    21‚Üí3. **Which skills are easily packaged as fixed-price with set deliverables?**
    22‚Üí4. **Do you have work samples** (images, video, PDFs) to market your project?
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí### Research Strategy
    25‚Üí- Browse through Project Catalog to see what other freelancers offer
    26‚Üí- Think about what you can offer that's unique or more specialized
    27‚Üí- Remember: You can edit every part of your project later
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí---
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí## How to Create a Project
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí### Access
    34‚Üí1. Go to **Find Work**
    35‚Üí2. Choose **Your services**
    36‚Üí3. Click green **Create Project** button
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí---
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí## Project Structure (Step-by-Step)
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí### 1. Project Overview
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí#### Title
    45‚Üí- Say what you offer in just a few words
    46‚Üí- Use search tags instead of making title longer
    47‚Üí- Do NOT repeat "You will get"
    48‚Üí- Follow regular capitalization rules
    49‚Üí- Proofread for spelling and grammar
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí**ScopeLock Examples:**
    52‚Üí```
    53‚ÜíEvidence Sprint: Working Prototype in 2-5 Days
    54‚ÜíAC.md + Acceptance Tests: Scope Lock Package
    55‚ÜíFull-Stack MVP with Pay-at-AC-Green Delivery
    56‚ÜíCHG-130 Change Control Implementation
    57‚Üí```
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí#### Category
    60‚Üí- Browse all categories to find best fit
    61‚Üí- Avoid selecting "Other" unless absolutely necessary
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí**Relevant Categories for ScopeLock:**
    64‚Üí- Web Development
    65‚Üí- Mobile Development
    66‚Üí- Software Development
    67‚Üí- AI Services
    68‚Üí- Technical Consulting
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí#### Specifics
    71‚Üí- Checkboxes based on your category help clients discover your project
    72‚Üí- Use image tagging options for better visibility
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí#### Search Tags
    75‚Üí- Add up to 5 tags with relevant keywords
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí**ScopeLock Tag Examples:**
    78‚Üí```
    79‚Üíacceptance-criteria, evidence-sprint, fixed-price, mvp, pay-at-delivery
    80‚Üítest-driven, scope-control, full-stack, rapid-prototyping, proof-based
    81‚Üí```
    82‚Üí
    83‚Üí---
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí### 2. Price and Scope
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí#### Package Tiers (up to 3)
    88‚Üí- **Starter** (lower price, basic scope)
    89‚Üí- **Standard** (mid-tier, most popular)
    90‚Üí- **Advanced** (premium, comprehensive)
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí**ScopeLock Tier Structure Example:**
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí| Tier | Price | Scope | Delivery | Revisions |
    95‚Üí|------|-------|-------|----------|-----------|
    96‚Üí| **Starter** | $3,000 | Evidence Sprint (prototype + delta) | 2-5 days | 2 |
    97‚Üí| **Standard** | $8,000 | AC.md + Acceptance Tests + MVP | 2-3 weeks | 3 |
    98‚Üí| **Advanced** | $20,000 | Full milestone with CHG-130 + /proof | 4-6 weeks | Unlimited |
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí#### Add-ons
   101‚Üí- Predefined or custom add-ons (e.g., extra-fast delivery)
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí**ScopeLock Add-on Examples:**
   104‚Üí```
   105‚Üí+ $500: Rush delivery (48-hour Evidence Sprint)
   106‚Üí+ $1,000: Additional milestone with CHG-130
   107‚Üí+ $750: Performance optimization (p95 < 200ms)
   108‚Üí+ $2,000: HIPAA compliance audit
   109‚Üí```
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí#### Pricing
   112‚Üí- Range: $5 USD to $500,000 USD
   113‚Üí
   114‚Üí#### Delivery Days
   115‚Üí- Set realistic and attractive timeframe
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí**ScopeLock Delivery Standards:**
   118‚Üí- Evidence Sprint: 2-5 days
   119‚Üí- AC.md + Tests: 1-2 weeks
   120‚Üí- Full MVP: 3-6 weeks
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí#### Revisions
   123‚Üí- Choose how many revisions are included during delivery period
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí**ScopeLock Approach:**
   126‚Üí- Revisions = fixing bugs against AC.md
   127‚Üí- NOT scope changes (those go through CHG-130)
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí---
   130‚Üí
   131‚Üí### 3. Gallery (Images & Video)
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí**Required:** Showcase samples of your work
   134‚Üí- Learn about adding images: [Upwork guide]
   135‚Üí- Learn about adding videos: [Upwork guide]
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí**ScopeLock Gallery Strategy:**
   138‚Üí1. **Hero image:** ScopeLock logo + tagline "Lock the scope. Prove the value."
   139‚Üí2. **AC.md example:** Screenshot of acceptance criteria structure
   140‚Üí3. **Proof Log:** Screenshot from scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/proof
   141‚Üí4. **Delta example:** Before/after metrics (e.g., "450ms ‚Üí 180ms p95")
   142‚Üí5. **Portfolio project:** La Serenissima (97 agents, 99.7% uptime)
   143‚Üí6. **Video (90s):** Demo walkthrough of Evidence Sprint process
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí---
   146‚Üí
   147‚Üí### 4. Client Requirements
   148‚Üí
   149‚Üí**Purpose:** List all information you need from the client before starting work.
   150‚Üí
   151‚Üí**Required step** before project begins.
   152‚Üí
   153‚Üí**ScopeLock Requirements Template:**
   154‚Üí```
   155‚Üí1. What problem are you trying to solve? (2-3 sentences)
   156‚Üí2. Who are the users/customers?
   157‚Üí3. What does success look like? (measurable outcomes)
   158‚Üí4. Do you have existing systems to integrate with?
   159‚Üí5. What is your timeline constraint? (if any)
   160‚Üí6. Budget range confirmed? (for package tier selection)
   161‚Üí7. Preferred communication method? (email, Slack, Telegram)
   162‚Üí```
   163‚Üí
   164‚Üí**Important:** Don't ask for personal contact info here (against ToS)
   165‚Üí
   166‚Üí---
   167‚Üí
   168‚Üí### 5. Description
   169‚Üí
   170‚ÜíThree parts: **Project Summary**, **Project Steps**, **FAQs**
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí#### Project Summary
   173‚ÜíExplain what sets you and your project apart.
   174‚Üí
   175‚Üí**ScopeLock Summary Template:**
   176‚Üí```
   177‚ÜíI deliver software against executable acceptance criteria. You pay only when tests are green.
   178‚Üí
   179‚ÜíWhat you get:
   180‚Üí‚Ä¢ AC.md (functional + non-functional criteria)
   181‚Üí‚Ä¢ Acceptance tests (automated, executable)
   182‚Üí‚Ä¢ Public proof log (tags + quantified deltas)
   183‚Üí‚Ä¢ CHG-130 change control (Swap ‚Ç¨0 or Add priced)
   184‚Üí
   185‚ÜíNo time estimates. No scope creep. No surprise costs.
   186‚Üí
   187‚ÜíEvidence Sprints: Working prototype + quantified delta in 2-5 days.
   188‚Üí
   189‚ÜíRecent proof:
   190‚Üí‚Ä¢ Multi-agent systems: 97+ agents, 6+ months production, 99.7% uptime
   191‚Üí‚Ä¢ Healthcare AI: 121+ deployments, HIPAA-aware
   192‚Üí‚Ä¢ Terminal Velocity: 1.1k GitHub stars
   193‚Üí
   194‚ÜíProcess:
   195‚Üí1. Co-write AC.md (functional, performance p95, quality thresholds)
   196‚Üí2. Build acceptance tests first
   197‚Üí3. Deliver when tests green
   198‚Üí4. Tag milestone (ac-green_project_date)
   199‚Üí5. You pay only at delivery
   200‚Üí
   201‚ÜíPortfolio + proof: scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/proof
   202‚Üí```
   203‚Üí
   204‚Üí#### Project Steps
   205‚ÜíBreak down your work process from start to finish.
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí**Important:** Client's job of submitting requirements, reviewing, and approving your work are already built in. Don't add these to your work steps.
   208‚Üí
   209‚Üí**ScopeLock Steps Template:**
   210‚Üí
   211‚Üí**Step 1: Kickoff + AC.md Co-Creation (Day 1-2)**
   212‚Üí- Review requirements and clarify scope
   213‚Üí- Co-write AC.md with functional + non-functional criteria
   214‚Üí- Define performance thresholds (e.g., p95 < 300ms)
   215‚Üí- Agree on verification method (test commands + seed data)
   216‚Üí- Tag baseline: `ac-baseline_[project]_[date]`
   217‚Üí
   218‚Üí**Step 2: Acceptance Tests First (Day 2-3)**
   219‚Üí- Write Playwright/PyTest tests for all AC.md criteria
   220‚Üí- Set up CI/CD pipeline
   221‚Üí- Create seed data for reproducible tests
   222‚Üí- Share test repo access for transparency
   223‚Üí
   224‚Üí**Step 3: Implementation (Days 4-10)**
   225‚Üí- Build features to pass acceptance tests
   226‚Üí- Commit regularly with clear messages
   227‚Üí- Run tests on every commit
   228‚Üí- Daily async updates via SYNC.md
   229‚Üí
   230‚Üí**Step 4: AC Green + Proof (Day 10-12)**
   231‚Üí- All acceptance tests pass (green CI)
   232‚Üí- Create DEMO.md (90-second walkthrough)
   233‚Üí- Create DELTA.md (quantified before/after metrics)
   234‚Üí- Tag milestone: `ac-green_[project]_[date]`
   235‚Üí- Publish to public proof log
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí**Step 5: Handoff + Documentation**
   238‚Üí- Deployment guide
   239‚Üí- Architecture documentation
   240‚Üí- Environment setup instructions
   241‚Üí- Performance monitoring dashboard access
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí#### FAQs
   244‚ÜíAdd answers to questions clients may ask.
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí**ScopeLock FAQ Template:**
   247‚Üí
   248‚Üí**Q: What if I want to change scope mid-project?**
   249‚ÜíA: We use CHG-130 change control. Changes are either Swap (equal/lower complexity, ‚Ç¨0, same milestone) or Add (new milestone, priced separately, you approve first).
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üí**Q: What if I'm not satisfied with the result?**
   252‚ÜíA: You only pay when acceptance tests are green. If tests don't pass, I fix until they do. If you want different functionality, that's a change request (CHG-130).
   253‚Üí
   254‚Üí**Q: How do I know it's done?**
   255‚ÜíA: When CI shows green tests for all AC.md criteria. No "90% done" ambiguity.
   256‚Üí
   257‚Üí**Q: Can I see examples of your work?**
   258‚ÜíA: Yes. Public proof log: scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/proof. Every milestone I've shipped with tags, deltas, and demos.
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí**Q: What if the project takes longer than estimated?**
   261‚ÜíA: Delivery days are targets, not guarantees. You pay at AC green, not at day count. If delays occur, I communicate via SYNC.md with reasons and new timeline.
   262‚Üí
   263‚Üí**Q: Do you work hourly?**
   264‚ÜíA: No. Fixed-price milestones only. Hourly creates incentive misalignment (slower = more money). I want fast delivery.
   265‚Üí
   266‚Üí**Q: What tech stack do you use?**
   267‚ÜíA: Next.js, FastAPI, PostgreSQL, Claude Code, multi-agent orchestration. Flexible based on project needs.
   268‚Üí
   269‚Üí**Q: Can you do rush delivery?**
   270‚ÜíA: Yes. Evidence Sprints in 2-5 days. Add-on: $500 for 48-hour delivery.
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí---
   273‚Üí
   274‚Üí### 6. Submit Project
   275‚Üí
   276‚Üí#### Concurrent Project Limit
   277‚ÜíSet maximum number of concurrent projects (up to 20).
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üí**ScopeLock Recommendation:** Start with 5 concurrent, adjust based on capacity.
   280‚Üí
   281‚Üí#### Project Stages
   282‚Üí
   283‚Üí**1. Under Review / Pending Approval**
   284‚Üí- Our team is reviewing for completeness and professionalism
   285‚Üí- You'll be notified when review is complete
   286‚Üí- **Top Rated/Top Rated Plus/Expert-Vetted:** Reviewed within 2 business days
   287‚Üí- **Others:** May take a few weeks due to volume
   288‚Üí
   289‚Üí**2. Approved / Accepted**
   290‚Üí- Project moves to active tab and is switched on automatically
   291‚Üí- You'll get confirmation email when it goes live
   292‚Üí- Clients can now purchase
   293‚Üí
   294‚Üí**3. Needs Changes**
   295‚Üí- You'll receive email with suggestions
   296‚Üí- You can edit and resubmit OR remove and start over
   297‚Üí
   298‚Üí---
   299‚Üí
   300‚Üí## What Upwork Reviews
   301‚Üí
   302‚Üí### Project Overview Review
   303‚Üí
   304‚Üí**Title:**
   305‚Üí- Service is clearly described
   306‚Üí- Service is in a category permitted on Upwork
   307‚Üí- No off-the-shelf products (crafts, software)
   308‚Üí- No services not covered by Upwork (e.g., dog grooming)
   309‚Üí
   310‚Üí**Note:** Can't sell pre-made products, only services you can deliver.
   311‚Üí
   312‚Üí---
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí### Pricing Section Review
   315‚Üí
   316‚ÜíUpwork checks custom add-ons and custom tiers for:

   320‚Üí---

   322‚Üí### Gallery Review
   323‚Üí
   324‚Üí**What they check:**
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí**1. Aesthetics**

   342‚Üí
   343‚Üí**ScopeLock Gallery Checklist:**

   346‚Üí- ‚úÖ Proof screenshots from live systems

   351‚Üí---
   352‚Üí
   353‚Üí### Description Review
   354‚Üí
   355‚ÜíAll three sections (summary, steps, FAQs) are checked for:

   431‚Üí## Common Rejection Reasons

   445‚Üí## Tips for Approval
   446‚Üí
   447‚Üí### Gallery

   463‚Üí2. **Competitive but not underpriced**
   464‚Üí3. **Clear tier differentiation**
   465‚Üí4. **Value-based** (outcomes, not hours)
   466‚Üí
   467‚Üí---
   468‚Üí
   469‚Üí## Editing After Approval
   470‚Üí
   471‚Üí### You Can Always:
   472‚Üí- Update images
   473‚Üí- Change description
   474‚Üí- Adjust pricing
   475‚Üí- Modify delivery days
   476‚Üí- Add/remove tiers
   477‚Üí- Update FAQs
   478‚Üí
   479‚Üí### Will Trigger Re-Review:
   480‚Üí- Category change (temporary removal)
   481‚Üí- Major content changes
   482‚Üí- Gallery updates
   483‚Üí
   484‚Üí### Visibility Toggle:
   485‚Üí- Turn project off temporarily without deleting
   486‚Üí- Switch back on anytime
   487‚Üí
   488‚Üí---
   489‚Üí
   490‚Üí## ScopeLock-Specific Guidelines
   491‚Üí
   492‚Üí### What to INCLUDE:
   493‚Üí‚úÖ Link to scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/proof (in description)
   494‚Üí‚úÖ Real metrics from La Serenissima, Terminal Velocity, etc.
   495‚Üí‚úÖ AC.md example screenshots
   496‚Üí‚úÖ Before/after deltas
   497‚Üí‚úÖ "Pay at AC green" positioning
   498‚Üí‚úÖ CHG-130 change control explanation
   499‚Üí
   500‚Üí### What to AVOID:
   501‚Üí‚ùå Personal email in requirements/description
   502‚Üí‚ùå Telegram/Discord handles
   503‚Üí‚ùå "Contact me outside Upwork"
   504‚Üí‚ùå Off-platform payment mentions
   505‚Üí‚ùå Competitor bashing
   506‚Üí‚ùå Unrealistic delivery promises ("24-hour MVP")
   507‚Üí
   508‚Üí---
   509‚Üí
   510‚Üí## Review Timeline
   511‚Üí
   512‚Üí**Top Rated / Top Rated Plus / Expert-Vetted:**
   513‚Üí- Reviewed within **2 business days**
   514‚Üí
   515‚Üí**Other freelancers:**
   516‚Üí- May take **a few weeks** due to volume
   517‚Üí
   518‚Üí**Notification:**
   519‚Üí- Email when review is complete (approved or needs changes)
   520‚Üí
   521‚Üí---
   522‚Üí
   523‚Üí## Best Practices
   524‚Üí
   525‚Üí### 1. Start with One High-Quality Project
   526‚Üí- Perfect your Evidence Sprint project first
   527‚Üí- Get approved, gather reviews
   528‚Üí- Then add more projects
   529‚Üí
   530‚Üí### 2. Use Real Work Samples
   531‚Üí- Screenshots from La Serenissima
   532‚Üí- Terminal Velocity GitHub stats
   533‚Üí- TherapyKin deployment metrics
   534‚Üí- Proof log entries
   535‚Üí
   536‚Üí### 3. Client-Centric Language
   537‚Üí- Focus on client outcomes, not your process
   538‚Üí- "You get a working prototype in 2-5 days" (not "I will build")
   539‚Üí- "You pay only at AC green" (not "I deliver when done")
   540‚Üí
   541‚Üí### 4. Specific, Verifiable Claims
   542‚Üí- "97 agents, 99.7% uptime, 6+ months" (not "highly reliable")
   543‚Üí- "1.1k GitHub stars" (not "popular project")
   544‚Üí- "p95 < 300ms" (not "fast performance")
   545‚Üí
   546‚Üí### 5. Differentiation
   547‚Üí- Show what makes you different (pay-at-AC-green, CHG-130)
   548‚Üí- Explain why it matters (no scope creep, no surprise costs)
   549‚Üí- Provide proof (link to /proof log)
   550‚Üí
   551‚Üí---
   552‚Üí
   553‚Üí## Next Steps
   554‚Üí
   555‚Üí1. **Create first project:** Evidence Sprint (easiest to approve)
   556‚Üí2. **Prepare gallery:** 6 images + 1 video (90s)
   557‚Üí3. **Write description:** Use templates above
   558‚Üí4. **Submit for review:** Expect 2 days - 2 weeks
   559‚Üí5. **Monitor:** Check for "Needs Changes" email
   560‚Üí6. **Iterate:** Edit based on feedback
   561‚Üí7. **Launch:** Turn on visibility when approved
   562‚Üí
   563‚Üí---
   564‚Üí
   565‚Üí**Reference:** https://support.upwork.com/hc/en-us/articles/13787478608539-How-to-create-a-project-in-Project-Catalog
   566‚Üí

## Two Different Approaches to Upwork

### 1. MISSION_SELECTION.md (Job Posts)
- **What:** Criteria for responding to individual client job posts

### 2. upwork_project_catalog.md (Service Packages)
- **What:** Create fixed-price packages clients can buy directly
- **Strategy:** Pre-package services (like "Evidence Sprint" or "AC.md + MVP")
- **Pricing:** $3,000-$50,000 per package tier
- **Examples:**

  - AC.md + MVP: $8,000-$15,000 (3-4 weeks)
  - CHG-130 Change Control: $20,000-$35,000 (4-6 weeks)

**Key Difference:**
- **Job Posts (MISSION_SELECTION):** Client posts need ‚Üí You propose ‚Üí They pick you
- **Project Catalog:** You post service ‚Üí Client buys directly ‚Üí You deliver

Both documents target different Upwork revenue channels. Was this the doc you were looking for?

Daily Job Search Strategy

  What we need to decide:

  1. Search Frequency
    - How many times per day should we check Upwork for new
  jobs?
    - Suggested: 3-4 times/day (morning, lunch, afternoon,
  evening)?
  2. Daily Application Target
    - How many proposals should we send per day?
    - Suggested: 5-10 proposals/day to start?
    - Quality over quantity or volume approach?
  3. Time Budget
    - How long to spend searching (1-2 hours/day)?
    - How long per proposal (15-30 min each)?
  4. Weekly Targets
    - Total proposals per week? (e.g., 30-50/week)
    - Expected conversion rate? (e.g., 10-20% win rate = 3-10
  jobs/week)
  5. Platform Strategy
    - Upwork only or also Contra/Fiverr/others?
    - Focus on one platform or spread across multiple?
  6. Follow-up Protocol
    - When to follow up on submitted proposals?
    - How to track which proposals are active?

  What do you think? Let's start with:
  - Applications per day target: How many?
  - Search times per day: How often?
  - Weekly revenue goal: What's realistic for Week 1 vs Month
  2?

Looking at our payment structure, team capacity, and MISSION_SELECTION.md criteria, let me give you a strategic recommendation:

## Strategic Analysis

### Revenue Requirements (From Payment Structure)

**Minimum viable:**
- 10 missions/month @ $600 avg = $6,000/month
- Team earns: $1,800 (livable in Nigeria/C√¥te d'Ivoire)
- Org costs: $2,100 (breaks even on AI/Claude Code)
- Nicolas: $1,500 (25% margin)

**Target state:**
- 15 missions/month @ $800 avg = $12,000/month
- Team: $3,600, Org: $2,100, Nicolas: $5,100

**This means we need 3-4 missions won per week** starting Month 2.

---

## My Recommendation (Phased Approach)

### Week 1-2: Learning Phase (Low Volume, High Quality)

**Daily Application Target:** 3-5 proposals/day
- **Why:** Bigbosexf is learning what works, Emma is calibrating confidence
- **Focus:** Perfect the proposal quality, not quantity
- **Win rate expectation:** 5-10% (1 in 20)
- **Expected outcome:** 1-2 jobs won in first 2 weeks

**Search Frequency:** 2-3 times/day
- **Times:** 9:00 AM WAT (catch overnight posts), 2:00 PM WAT (lunch rush), 7:00 PM WAT (evening posts)
- **Why:** Upwork jobs get most proposals in first 2-6 hours
- **Tool:** RSS feed monitoring (future automation Feature 4)

**Time Budget:**
- Search: 30-45 min/session = 1.5-2h/day
- Proposal writing: 15-20 min each = 1-1.5h/day
- **Total:** 2.5-3.5h/day for Bigbosexf

**Weekly Target:**
- Proposals sent: 15-25/week
- Jobs won: 1-2 (if lucky)
- Revenue: $200-800

---

### Week 3-4: Ramp-Up Phase (Moderate Volume)

**Daily Application Target:** 5-8 proposals/day
- **Why:** Bigbosexf knows the patterns, Emma's templates are proven
- **Win rate expectation:** 10-15% (improving with testimonials)
- **Expected outcome:** 2-3 jobs won per week

**Search Frequency:** 3-4 times/day
- Add 11:00 AM WAT check (mid-morning wave)
- **Why:** More frequent checks = earlier applications = higher visibility

**Time Budget:**
- Search: 1-1.5h/day (faster pattern recognition)
- Proposals: 10-15 min each (templates refined) = 1-2h/day
- **Total:** 2-3h/day

**Weekly Target:**
- Proposals: 30-40/week
- Jobs won: 2-3
- Revenue: $800-1,800

---

### Month 2+: Production Phase (High Volume, Automated)

**Daily Application Target:** 10-15 proposals/day
- **Why:** Emma RSS auto-send (Feature 4) handles high confidence (80%+)
- **Win rate expectation:** 15-20% (proven track record + testimonials)
- **Expected outcome:** 3-5 jobs won per week

**Search Frequency:** Automated RSS + 1 manual check
- **Morning brief** (8:00 AM WAT) shows new high-value jobs
- **Emma auto-sends** confidence >80% proposals
- **Bigbosexf reviews** edge cases only

**Time Budget:**
- Bigbosexf: 1-1.5h/day (review Emma's work, handle edge cases)
- Emma: Automated (Feature 4)
- **Total:** 1.5h/day human time

**Weekly Target:**
- Proposals: 50-70/week
- Jobs won: 5-8
- Revenue: $3,000-6,000

---

## Platform Strategy

### Week 1-4: Upwork Only

**Why focus on one platform:**
- ‚úÖ Learn one system deeply (proposal patterns, client psychology)
- ‚úÖ Build reputation in one place (JSS, testimonials compound)
- ‚úÖ Simpler tracking (one inbox, one process)
- ‚úÖ Emma's MISSION_SELECTION.md is Upwork-specific

**Contra/Fiverr later:**
- **Contra:** Month 2+ (higher-value clients, less competition)
- **Fiverr:** Not recommended (race to bottom pricing, wrong client type)

### Why Not Spread Early:

**Opportunity cost:**
- 5 proposals/day on Upwork = concentrated reputation building
- 2 proposals each on 3 platforms = diluted, no momentum

**Learning curve:**
- Each platform has different proposal style, client expectations, algorithms
- Mastering one = higher win rate than mediocre on three

---

## Follow-Up Protocol

### When to Follow-Up

**24-48h after submission:**
- If client viewed proposal but didn't respond
- Message: "Hi [Name], following up on my proposal. Happy to clarify any questions about the Evidence Sprint approach or timeline. Available for a quick call if helpful."

**5-7 days after submission:**
- If client hasn't viewed proposal
- Don't follow up (they're not interested)

**When client responds with questions:**
- Respond within 2 hours during WAT business hours (9 AM - 6 PM)
- Use Maya's templates for professional, clear answers

### Tracking System

**Emma's leads-tracker.md:**
- Logs every proposal sent
- Tracks status: submitted ‚Üí viewed ‚Üí interview ‚Üí won/lost
- Follow-up dates auto-calculated (24h, 48h flags)

**Weekly review (Friday):**
- Win rate this week: X/Y proposals
- Average response time: X hours
- Most common rejection reasons
- Adjust strategy for next week

---

## Realistic Revenue Projections

### Week 1 (Conservative)

**Effort:**
- 3 proposals/day √ó 5 days = 15 proposals
- Win rate: 5% = 0.75 jobs won

**Reality check:** Might not win anything Week 1 (new profile, no reviews)

**Expected revenue:** $0-400

---

### Week 2 (With Testimonial from Week 1)

**Effort:**
- 4 proposals/day √ó 5 days = 20 proposals
- Win rate: 8% (one testimonial) = 1.6 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $400-800

---

### Week 3-4 (Momentum Building)

**Effort:**
- 6 proposals/day √ó 10 days = 60 proposals
- Win rate: 12% (2-3 testimonials) = 7 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $1,500-3,000 (over 2 weeks)

---

### Month 2 (With Track Record)

**Effort:**
- 10 proposals/day √ó 20 days = 200 proposals
- Win rate: 15% (5+ testimonials, JSS >90%) = 30 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $6,000-12,000/month

---

## My Specific Recommendations (Start This Week)

### Phase 1: Week 1-2 (RIGHT NOW)

**Daily targets:**
- ‚úÖ **3-5 proposals/day** (quality over quantity)
- ‚úÖ **2-3 search sessions/day** (9 AM, 2 PM, 7 PM WAT)
- ‚úÖ **2.5-3.5h total time** (search + proposals)

**Weekly targets:**
- ‚úÖ **15-25 proposals sent**
- ‚úÖ **1-2 jobs won** (if lucky, might be 0)
- ‚úÖ **$200-800 revenue**

**Platform:**
- ‚úÖ **Upwork only** (master one before spreading)

**Success criteria:**
- [ ] Bigbosexf comfortable finding jobs matching MISSION_SELECTION.md
- [ ] Emma's proposal templates refined
- [ ] 1 testimonial captured
- [ ] Understand what proposals get responses

---

### Decision Points for You

**Quick decisions needed:**

1. **Applications per day (Week 1):** 3-5 or go higher?
   - My recommendation: **3-5** (learn before scaling)

2. **Search times:** 2-3 times/day or more?
   - My recommendation: **3 times/day** (9 AM, 2 PM, 7 PM WAT)

3. **Week 1 revenue goal:** Realistic target?
   - My recommendation: **$200-400** (might be $0, don't be discouraged)

4. **Month 2 revenue goal:** What are we aiming for?
   - My recommendation: **$6,000-8,000** (10-12 missions @ $600-700 avg)

**Which of these do you want to adjust?** Or should I formalize this into a tracking template so we can measure actual vs. projected?

input.content:
# ScopeLock Daily Job Search Strategy

**Version:** 1.0
**Created:** 2025-11-05
**Owner:** Alexis (Strategy) + Emma (Execution) + Bigbosexf (Hunter)
**Purpose:** Systematic approach to finding and winning Upwork/Contra missions

---

## Executive Summary

**Goal:** Generate consistent pipeline of $6,000-12,000/month revenue through systematic job search and proposal submission.

**Approach:** Start at moderate volume (5-8 proposals/day), scale to high volume (10-15/day) with automation, add Contra in Phase 2.

**Success Metrics:**
- Phase 1 (Week 1-4): 2-3 jobs won/week, $800-1,800/week revenue
- Phase 2 (Month 2-3): 3-5 jobs won/week, $1,500-3,000/week revenue, Contra integrated
- Phase 3 (Month 4+): 5-8 jobs won/week, $3,000-6,000/week revenue, mostly automated

---

## Phase 1: Moderate Volume Upwork (Week 1-4)

### Daily Targets

**Applications:** 5-8 proposals/day
- **Why moderate volume:** Balance quality with pipeline building
- **Focus:** Perfect proposal templates while building momentum
- **Expected win rate:** 10-15% (1 in 7-10)

**Search Frequency:** 3-4 times/day
- **9:00 AM WAT:** Morning sweep (catch overnight posts)
- **11:00 AM WAT:** Mid-morning check (secondary wave)
- **2:00 PM WAT:** Afternoon sweep (lunch posts)
- **7:00 PM WAT:** Evening check (end-of-day posts)

**Why these times:**
- Upwork jobs get most proposals in first 2-6 hours
- Early application = higher visibility to client
- Multiple checks = don't miss high-value jobs

**Time Budget:**
- **Search:** 30-40 min/session √ó 4 = 2-2.5h/day
- **Proposals:** 15-20 min each √ó 6 avg = 1.5-2h/day
- **Follow-ups:** 15-30 min/day
- **Total:** 4-5h/day (Bigbosexf)

### Weekly Targets

**Proposals sent:** 30-40/week (5-8/day √ó 5 days)
**Jobs won:** 2-3/week
**Revenue:** $800-1,800/week
**Win rate target:** 10-15%

### Platform Strategy

**Upwork only** for first 4 weeks

**Why:**
- ‚úÖ Learn one system deeply (proposal patterns, client psychology, JSS algorithm)
- ‚úÖ Build concentrated reputation (testimonials compound faster)
- ‚úÖ Simpler tracking (one inbox, one process)
- ‚úÖ Emma's MISSION_SELECTION.md is Upwork-optimized

**Contra integration:** Phase 2 (Week 5+)

### Success Criteria (End of Week 4)

- [ ] 120-160 proposals sent total
- [ ] 8-12 jobs won
- [ ] $3,200-7,200 revenue accumulated
- [ ] 5+ testimonials captured
- [ ] JSS >85% (if enough jobs completed)
- [ ] Win rate stabilized (know what works)
- [ ] Proposal templates refined (Emma's confidence >80% accurate)

---

## Phase 2: High Volume + Contra Integration (Month 2-3)

### Daily Targets

**Applications:** 10-15 proposals/day total
- **Upwork:** 7-10/day
- **Contra:** 3-5/day (new platform)

**Search Frequency:**
- **Upwork:** 3 times/day (automated RSS alerts + manual checks)
- **Contra:** 2 times/day (morning + evening sweep)

**Time Budget:**
- **Upwork:** 2-3h/day (partially automated with Emma RSS)
- **Contra:** 1.5-2h/day (learning new platform)
- **Follow-ups:** 30-45 min/day
- **Total:** 4-5.5h/day (automation reduces Bigbosexf's load)

### Weekly Targets

**Proposals sent:** 50-70/week
- Upwork: 35-50/week
- Contra: 15-20/week

**Jobs won:** 3-5/week total
- Upwork: 2-4/week
- Contra: 1-2/week (lower win rate initially)

**Revenue:** $1,500-3,000/week
**Win rate target:** 15-20% (Upwork), 5-10% (Contra learning curve)

### Contra Integration Strategy

**Why add Contra in Phase 2:**
- ‚úÖ Higher-value clients ($800-2,000 missions vs $200-600 Upwork)
- ‚úÖ Less competition (smaller platform, more curated)
- ‚úÖ Better client quality (verified companies, not individuals)
- ‚úÖ Complementary to Upwork (different client psychology)

**Contra-specific approach:**
- Use existing portfolio (La Serenissima, Terminal Velocity, TherapyKin)
- Emphasize "Evidence Sprint" positioning (Contra clients love speed)
- Target AI integration missions (Contra skews tech-forward)
- See: `/docs/marketing/contra_tactical_guide.md` for platform specifics

**Week 5 Contra ramp-up:**
- Week 5: 2-3 proposals/day (learning)
- Week 6: 3-4 proposals/day
- Week 7-8: 4-5 proposals/day (standard)

### Success Criteria (End of Month 3)

- [ ] 200-280 proposals sent total (Upwork + Contra)
- [ ] 12-20 jobs won/month
- [ ] $6,000-12,000/month revenue
- [ ] 15+ testimonials captured
- [ ] Contra profile established (2-3 testimonials)
- [ ] Win rate 15-20% Upwork, 10-15% Contra
- [ ] Emma RSS auto-send deployed (Feature 4)

---

## Phase 3: Automated High Volume (Month 4+)

### Daily Targets

**Applications:** 10-15 proposals/day (mostly automated)
- **Emma auto-sends:** 80%+ confidence jobs (7-10/day)
- **Bigbosexf reviews:** Edge cases only (3-5/day)

**Search Frequency:** Automated + 1 manual check
- **Morning brief** (8:00 AM WAT): AI-generated job list for the day
- **Emma auto-send:** Throughout the day as RSS detects jobs
- **Evening review** (6:00 PM WAT): Bigbosexf checks edge cases

**Time Budget:**
- **Bigbosexf:** 1.5-2h/day (review Emma's work, handle edge cases, follow-ups)
- **Emma:** Automated (Feature 4 + 8)
- **Total:** 2h/day human time (down from 5h in Phase 1)

### Weekly Targets

**Proposals sent:** 50-75/week
**Jobs won:** 5-8/week
**Revenue:** $3,000-6,000/week
**Win rate target:** 20-25% (proven track record)

### Success Criteria (Steady State)

- [ ] 200-300 proposals/month automated
- [ ] 20-32 jobs won/month
- [ ] $12,000-20,000/month revenue
- [ ] 30+ testimonials
- [ ] JSS >95%
- [ ] Minimal human intervention (Emma handles 80%+)

---

## Job Selection Criteria (Per MISSION_SELECTION.md)

### Green Light (ALL Must Match)

1. **Budget:** $200-$600 (Week 1-4), $600-$1,500 (Month 2+)
2. **Stack Match:** 80%+ our tools (Python/JS/TS, Next.js, FastAPI)
3. **Clear Deliverable:** Can write AC.md in 5 minutes
4. **Timeline:** 2-7 days
5. **Client Quality:** 3+ green flags (payment verified, $1000+ spent, 4.5+ rating)
6. **Competition:** <15 proposals

### Priority Mission Types

**Tier 1 (Highest Priority):**
- PDF/Document Parsing: $400-800, 6-12h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Email Processing: $350-600, 8-14h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Telegram Bots: $200-400, 4-6h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Landing Pages: $200-400, 6-8h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

**Tier 2 (Good Revenue):**
- CRUD Dashboards: $400-800, 12-20h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Simple APIs: $200-400, 4-6h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
- Payment Integration: $400-800, 8-12h ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

**Auto-Pass:**
- Mobile apps (React Native, Flutter)
- ML/Data Science training
- Game development
- Legacy code modernization
- "Ongoing maintenance" without clear deliverables

### Emma's Scoring System

**Total: 0-13 points**
- Stack match: 0-3 points
- Budget fit: 0-2 points
- Clear scope: 0-2 points
- Client quality: 0-2 points
- Timeline: 0-1 point
- AI integration fit: 0-3 points

**Decision:**
- **8-13 points:** Strong yes, write proposal
- **6-7 points:** Maybe, ask Alexis/NLR
- **0-5 points:** Pass

---

## Daily Workflow

### Morning Routine (9:00 AM WAT)

**Bigbosexf:**
1. Check Upwork RSS feed or manual search
2. Filter jobs by MISSION_SELECTION.md criteria
3. Score each job using Emma's system (8-13 = write proposal)
4. Identify 2-3 high-priority jobs for the morning

**Emma:**
1. Analyze high-priority jobs
2. Draft proposals using appropriate template
3. Send to Bigbosexf for review

**Bigbosexf:**
1. Review Emma's proposals (5-10 min each)
2. Approve or request revision
3. Submit approved proposals

**Target:** 2-3 proposals submitted by 11:00 AM

---

### Mid-Morning Check (11:00 AM WAT)

**Bigbosexf:**
1. Quick Upwork sweep (15-20 min)
2. Flag any urgent/high-value jobs
3. Emma drafts if needed
4. Submit 1-2 more proposals

**Target:** 1-2 proposals submitted by 12:00 PM

---

### Afternoon Sweep (2:00 PM WAT)

**Bigbosexf:**
1. Check responses to morning proposals
2. Respond to client questions (within 2h)
3. Search for new jobs
4. Emma drafts proposals

**Target:** 1-2 proposals submitted by 4:00 PM

---

### Evening Check (7:00 PM WAT)

**Bigbosexf:**
1. Final Upwork sweep (20-30 min)
2. Flag jobs for next morning if no time to write now
3. Follow up on proposals viewed but not responded to (24-48h rule)
4. Update leads-tracker.md

**Target:** 1-2 proposals submitted or flagged for tomorrow

**End-of-day total:** 5-8 proposals submitted

---

## Weekly Rhythm

### Monday Morning (30 min)

**Review last week:**
- Proposals sent: X
- Jobs won: Y
- Win rate: Y/X = Z%
- Revenue: $A
- Most common rejection reasons

**Plan this week:**
- Target proposals: X
- Target wins: Y
- Focus areas (e.g., more AI integration jobs)

---

### Wednesday Mid-Week Check (15 min)

**Progress check:**
- On track for weekly proposal target?
- Any proposals need follow-up?
- Adjust strategy if needed

---

### Friday Retrospective (30 min)

**Data analysis:**
- Win rate by job type (landing pages vs APIs vs AI integration)
- Win rate by budget range ($200-400 vs $400-600)
- Response rate by proposal template
- Average time from proposal to win

**Strategy adjustments:**
- What worked this week?
- What didn't work?
- How to improve next week?

**Update tracking:**
- Emma's leads-tracker.md
- Alexis's financial dashboard
- SYNC.md with findings

---

## Follow-Up Protocol

### When to Follow-Up

**24-48h after submission:**
- **Trigger:** Client viewed proposal but didn't respond
- **Action:** Send polite follow-up
- **Template:**
  ```
  Hi [Name],

  Following up on my proposal for [Job Title]. Happy to clarify any questions about the Evidence Sprint approach or timeline.

  Available for a quick call if helpful to discuss how we'd tackle [specific requirement from job post].

  Best,
  Bigbosexf
  ```

**When client responds with questions:**
- **Response SLA:** <2 hours during WAT business hours (9 AM - 6 PM)
- **Use:** Maya's templates for professional, clear answers
- **Escalate to:** Nicolas if client asks technical questions beyond scope

**When to stop following up:**
- **5-7 days:** If client hasn't viewed proposal
- **After 1 follow-up:** If client viewed but still no response
- **When job is filled:** Upwork shows "Contract awarded"

### Tracking System

**Emma's leads-tracker.md:**
- Logs every proposal sent (date, job title, budget, platform)
- Tracks status: submitted ‚Üí viewed ‚Üí interview ‚Üí won/lost
- Auto-calculates follow-up dates (24h, 48h flags)
- Weekly summary (proposals sent, win rate, revenue)

**Review cadence:**
- Daily: Check for follow-up flags
- Weekly: Calculate win rate and adjust strategy
- Monthly: Identify patterns (which job types win most)

---

## Revenue Projections

### Week 1-4 (Phase 1: Moderate Volume Upwork)

**Effort:**
- 5-8 proposals/day √ó 20 days = 100-160 proposals/month
- Win rate: 10-15% = 10-24 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $3,200-7,200/month

**Breakdown by week:**
- Week 1: $400-800 (1-2 jobs, learning)
- Week 2: $600-1,200 (2-3 jobs, templates refined)
- Week 3: $800-1,600 (2-4 jobs, momentum)
- Week 4: $1,000-2,000 (3-5 jobs, testimonials help)

---

### Month 2-3 (Phase 2: High Volume + Contra)

**Effort:**
- Upwork: 7-10 proposals/day √ó 20 days = 140-200/month
- Contra: 3-5 proposals/day √ó 20 days = 60-100/month
- Total: 200-300 proposals/month
- Win rate: 15-20% Upwork, 10-15% Contra = 28-60 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $6,000-12,000/month

**Platform split:**
- Upwork: $4,000-8,000 (20-40 jobs @ $200-600)
- Contra: $2,000-4,000 (8-20 jobs @ $800-1,500)

---

### Month 4+ (Phase 3: Automated High Volume)

**Effort:**
- Emma auto-sends: 10-15 proposals/day √ó 20 days = 200-300/month
- Win rate: 20-25% = 40-75 jobs won

**Expected revenue:** $12,000-20,000/month

**Team capacity check:**
- 40-75 jobs/month √∑ 4 weeks = 10-19 jobs/week
- 3 developers (Reanance, Kara, Bigbosexf) = 3-6 concurrent jobs each
- **This is FEASIBLE** with proper handoffs

---

## Platform Strategy

### Phase 1 (Week 1-4): Upwork Only

**Focus:**
- Master Upwork proposal templates
- Build JSS and testimonials
- Understand client psychology
- Refine MISSION_SELECTION.md criteria

**Why not spread:**
- Concentrated reputation building (testimonials compound)
- Simpler tracking (one system to learn)
- Emma's templates are Upwork-optimized

---

### Phase 2 (Month 2-3): Add Contra

**Contra advantages:**
- Higher-value clients ($800-2,000 avg vs $200-600 Upwork)
- Less competition (smaller, more curated platform)
- Better client quality (verified companies)
- Faster payments (Contra pays faster than Upwork)

**Contra approach:**
- Emphasize portfolio (La Serenissima, Terminal Velocity proof)
- Position as "Evidence Sprint" specialist
- Target AI integration and web app missions
- Use contra_tactical_guide.md for platform-specific tactics

**Integration timeline:**
- Week 5: 2-3 Contra proposals/day (learning)
- Week 6: 3-4 Contra proposals/day
- Week 7-8: 4-5 Contra proposals/day (standard)

---

### Phase 3 (Month 4+): Evaluate Additional Platforms

**Potential additions:**
- **Toptal:** High-value clients, but strict vetting
- **Gun.io:** Developer-focused, good rates
- **Freelancer.com:** Low priority (price competition)
- **Fiverr:** Not recommended (race to bottom)

**Decision criteria:**
- Only add if Upwork + Contra can't sustain $20k/month
- Platform must support fixed-price, evidence-based delivery
- Client quality must be high (no tire-kickers)

---

## Success Metrics Dashboard

**Track weekly in Alexis's financial dashboard:**

### Lead Generation Metrics
- Proposals sent (Upwork / Contra / Total)
- Jobs viewed by client (engagement rate)
- Interview requests (interest rate)
- Jobs won (conversion rate)

### Quality Metrics
- Win rate % (jobs won √∑ proposals sent)
- Average response time (hours)
- Follow-up conversion (follow-ups ‚Üí wins)
- Platform distribution (Upwork vs Contra)

### Revenue Metrics
- Revenue won this week
- Revenue delivered this week
- Revenue collected this week (accounting for Upwork delays)
- Average job value

### Efficiency Metrics
- Time per proposal (minutes)
- Proposals per hour
- Cost per acquisition (time √ó $100/hr √∑ jobs won)
- Emma automation % (Phase 3)

---

## Risk Mitigation

### Risk: Low Win Rate (<10%)

**Symptoms:**
- Proposals viewed but not winning
- No interview requests

**Diagnosis:**
- Check proposal quality (too generic?)
- Check budget positioning (too high?)
- Check client targeting (wrong fit?)

**Solution:**
- A/B test proposal templates
- Lower bids temporarily (build testimonials)
- Narrow job selection criteria (higher quality leads)

---

### Risk: High Win Rate (>30%) But Low Revenue

**Symptoms:**
- Winning lots of jobs but all low-budget
- High volume, low profitability

**Diagnosis:**
- Targeting only $200-300 jobs
- Not bidding on higher-value missions

**Solution:**
- Shift to $400-800 tier missions
- Use testimonials to justify higher pricing
- Focus on AI integration (higher perceived value)

---

### Risk: Can't Keep Up With Won Jobs

**Symptoms:**
- Won 10 jobs, only 3 developers
- Delivery delays, quality issues

**Diagnosis:**
- Win rate too high for current capacity
- Need to slow down or hire

**Solution:**
- Reduce proposals temporarily (5/day ‚Üí 3/day)
- Increase prices (natural demand throttle)
- Hire 4th developer (per Alexis team management plan)

---

### Risk: Platform Saturation (Too Many Proposals, Low Visibility)

**Symptoms:**
- Proposals not even viewed by clients
- Jobs have 30+ proposals already

**Diagnosis:**
- Applying too late (jobs already have many bids)
- Not targeting niche enough

**Solution:**
- Apply within first 2 hours of job posting
- Use RSS alerts for instant notifications (Feature 4)
- Target more specialized missions (AI integration)

---

## Quick Decision Reference

### Daily Application Target

**Phase 1 (Week 1-4):** 5-8 proposals/day
**Phase 2 (Month 2-3):** 10-15 proposals/day (Upwork + Contra)
**Phase 3 (Month 4+):** 10-15 proposals/day (mostly automated)

### Search Frequency

**Phase 1:** 3-4 times/day (9 AM, 11 AM, 2 PM, 7 PM WAT)
**Phase 2:** 3-4 times/day + Contra 2 times/day
**Phase 3:** Automated RSS + 1 manual review

### Weekly Revenue Goals

**Week 1-4:** $800-1,800/week
**Month 2-3:** $1,500-3,000/week
**Month 4+:** $3,000-6,000/week

### Platform Strategy

**Phase 1:** Upwork only
**Phase 2:** Upwork + Contra (70/30 split)
**Phase 3:** Upwork + Contra (evaluate others)

---

## Next Steps (This Week)

### For Bigbosexf (Hunter)

**Today:**
- [ ] Read MISSION_SELECTION.md (refresh criteria)
- [ ] Set up Upwork RSS alerts (if available)
- [ ] Review Emma's proposal templates
- [ ] Search Upwork now (find 3-5 jobs matching criteria)

**Tomorrow:**
- [ ] Submit 5-8 proposals (use Emma's assistance)
- [ ] Log in leads-tracker.md
- [ ] Set follow-up reminders (24h, 48h)

**This Week:**
- [ ] 5-8 proposals/day √ó 5 days = 25-40 proposals
- [ ] Track win rate
- [ ] Capture first testimonial if job won

---

### For Emma (Scout)

**Today:**
- [ ] Review proposal templates (process-skeptical, process-oriented)
- [ ] Set up leads-tracker.md structure
- [ ] Prepare to draft proposals when Bigbosexf finds jobs

**This Week:**
- [ ] Draft 25-40 proposals
- [ ] Track which templates win most
- [ ] Refine confidence scoring (learn from wins/losses)

---

### For Alexis (Strategist)

**This Week:**
- [ ] Set up weekly financial tracking dashboard
- [ ] Monitor win rate and revenue
- [ ] Adjust strategy if <10% win rate after 20 proposals

**End of Week 4:**
- [ ] Full retrospective (what worked, what didn't)
- [ ] Decide: move to Phase 2 or extend Phase 1
- [ ] Plan Contra integration timeline

---

## Related Documents

**Job Selection:**
- `/citizens/emma/MISSION_SELECTION.md` ‚≠ê‚≠ê AUTHORITATIVE - Which jobs to target
- `/docs/marketing/upwork_project_catalog.md` - Service packages (alternative revenue channel)

**Proposal Writing:**
- `/docs/marketing/proposal_framework.md` - Proposal templates and structure
- `/docs/marketing/communication_guide.md` - Client communication principles
- `/docs/marketing/contra_tactical_guide.md` - Contra platform specifics (Phase 2)

**Tracking:**
- `/citizens/emma/leads-tracker.md` - Proposal and lead tracking
- `/citizens/alexis/TODOS.md` - Strategic action items
- `/citizens/SYNC.md` - Team status updates

**Financial:**
- `/docs/core/payment-structure.md` - Team compensation structure
- `/citizens/alexis/ROADMAP.md` - Strategic phases and metrics

---

**Last Updated:** 2025-11-05
**Status:** Active - Phase 1 starts immediately (moderate volume Upwork)
**Review Cadence:** Weekly adjustments, monthly retrospectives

---

## Questions or Adjustments?

**Contact:**
- Strategy questions ‚Üí Alexis
- Job selection questions ‚Üí Emma (via MISSION_SELECTION.md)
- Proposal writing questions ‚Üí Emma (via proposal_framework.md)
- Platform questions ‚Üí Bigbosexf or NLR

**Update this document when:**
- Win rate significantly differs from projections (>5% variance)
- Revenue targets not met for 2+ weeks
- Platform strategy changes (add/remove platforms)
- Team capacity changes (hire/lose developers)

input.content:
# Mission Evaluation & Improvement Process

**Version:** 1.0
**Created:** 2025-11-05
**Owner:** Alexis (Strategy) + Sofia (Quality) + All Team Members
**Purpose:** Systematic process for evaluating mission performance and implementing improvements

---

## Executive Summary

**Goal:** Learn from every mission to improve quality, speed, collaboration, and profitability.

**Approach:** Structured evaluation after each mission (immediate feedback) + weekly aggregation (pattern recognition) + monthly retrospectives (strategic adjustments).

**Key Principle:** Blame-free improvement culture. We evaluate systems and processes, not people. Everyone contributes to making the next mission better.

---

## Per-Mission Retrospective (Detailed Process)

### Preparation (Before Meeting)

**Sofia collects data:**
- Mission timeline (planned vs actual)
- AC.md completeness (all criteria met?)
- DoD checklist completion %
- Bug count (critical/high/medium/low)
- Client feedback (satisfaction, change requests)
- Git activity (commit frequency, PR turnaround)
- Time spent per phase (spec, implementation, QA, delivery)

**Each participant prepares:**
- What went well (1-3 items)
- What didn't go well (1-3 items)
- What to improve next time (1-2 specific actions)

---

### Meeting Structure (30-45 min)

**Part 1: Metrics Review (5 min) - Sofia presents**

```
Mission: #47 - AI Chatbot Integration
Client: TechCorp

QUALITY:
‚úÖ AC.md: 12/12 criteria met (100%)
‚úÖ DoD: 18/18 items complete (100%)
‚ö†Ô∏è Bugs found: 3 medium, 1 low (QA caught all before client)

TIMELINE:
- Spec phase: Planned 2 days ‚Üí Actual 2 days ‚úÖ
- Implementation: Planned 3 days ‚Üí Actual 4 days ‚ö†Ô∏è (Rafael code gen delayed)

‚úÖ Client satisfaction: 5/5 (happy with quality)

‚ö†Ô∏è Bigbosexf found bugs that should have been caught in implementation
```

---

**Part 2: What Went Well (10 min) - Round robin**

**Format:** Each person shares 1-3 things that went well

**Example responses:**

**Reanance (Specifier):**
- "AC.md was crystal clear this time. All 12 criteria were testable."
- "Client responded to questions within 2 hours (very engaged)."

**Kara (Developer):**
- "Rafael's code was 95% complete. Just needed minor tweaks."
- "Deployment to Render was smooth (followed Inna's GUIDE exactly)."

**Bigbosexf (QA):**
- "Sofia's DoD checklist caught the mobile issue before I even tested."
- "Client was very responsive during QA phase."

**Rafael (AI Citizen - written input):**
- "Inna's MECHANISM section was detailed. Generated code matched architecture perfectly."
- "No back-and-forth on implementation approach. Spec was complete."

**Sofia (QA Verifier):**
- "DoD checklist worked well. Developer knew exactly what to verify."
- "All acceptance tests passed on first try after bug fixes."

**Maya (Client Communication):**
- "Client loved the Evidence Sprint demo. Shared it with their team."
- "Weekly status update template worked perfectly."

---

**Part 3: What Didn't Go Well (10 min) - Round robin**

**Format:** Each person shares 1-3 problems (no blame, just facts)

**Example responses:**

**Reanance:**
- "Waited 6 hours for Rafael to generate code. I was blocked."
- "Client asked a question I couldn't answer (about API rate limits). Had to escalate to Rafael."

**Kara:**
- "Found 3 medium bugs during implementation. Rafael's code didn't handle edge cases."
- "Deployment guide was missing environment variable setup. Had to figure it out."

**Bigbosexf:**
- "QA took 2 days instead of 1. Bugs should have been caught earlier."
- "One bug only appeared on mobile Safari. Didn't test that initially."

**Rafael:**
- "I was working on another mission when Reanance requested code. Context switching delayed me."
- "Edge cases weren't in AC.md. Generated code based on spec, which was incomplete."

**Sofia:**
- "DoD checklist didn't include mobile testing. That's why bug was missed."
- "Acceptance tests didn't cover error handling edge cases."

**Maya:**
- "Client asked why delivery was late. I didn't have a good answer (didn't know about blocker)."
- "Had to explain technical issues to client without full context."

---

**Part 4: Root Cause Analysis (10 min) - Group discussion**

**Facilitator (Sofia) groups issues into themes:**

**Theme 1: Rafael availability/context switching**
- Reanance waited 6h for code generation
- Rafael was working on another mission

**Root cause:**
- No scheduling system for Rafael's time
- Multiple missions competing for same resource

**Theme 2: Incomplete AC.md (edge cases)**
- Edge cases not specified
- Rafael generated code based on incomplete spec
- Bugs found later in QA

**Root cause:**
- Inna's BEHAVIOR_SPEC didn't include error handling section
- Reanance didn't ask "what if user enters invalid data?"

**Theme 3: Mobile testing not in DoD**
- Bug only appeared on mobile Safari
- DoD checklist didn't mention mobile

**Root cause:**
- DoD template is generic, not customized per mission
- Sofia didn't review client's user base (60% mobile)

**Theme 4: Communication gaps (Maya ‚Üî Team)**
- Maya didn't know about 6h blocker
- Couldn't explain delay to client

**Root cause:**
- No real-time blocker notification system
- SYNC.md updated once/day (not real-time)

---

**Part 5: Improvement Actions (10 min) - Specific, Assignable**

**Format:** Convert root causes into concrete actions with owners

**Action 1: Rafael Scheduling System**
- **Problem:** Rafael availability/context switching
- **Action:** Create "Rafael Request Queue" in graph
  - Reanance submits code generation request with priority
  - Rafael works FIFO (first in, first out)
  - Estimated turnaround: 2-4h (batched)
- **Owner:** Inna (create queue system spec)
- **Deadline:** Before next mission starts
- **Success metric:** No developer waits >4h for Rafael

**Action 2: Edge Case Checklist for AC.md**
- **Problem:** Incomplete AC.md (missing edge cases)
- **Action:** Inna adds "Edge Cases & Error Handling" section to BEHAVIOR_SPEC template
  - What if user enters invalid input?
  - What if API is down?
  - What if database connection fails?
  - What if rate limit exceeded?
- **Owner:** Inna (update template)
- **Deadline:** Today (update template immediately)
- **Success metric:** Next mission AC.md has edge cases section

**Action 3: Mission-Specific DoD (Not Generic)**
- **Problem:** DoD didn't include mobile testing
- **Action:** Sofia reviews AC.md and customizes DoD per mission
  - If client's users are mobile (check during kickoff) ‚Üí add mobile testing
  - If mission has API integrations ‚Üí add API error handling tests
  - If mission has payments ‚Üí add fraud/security tests
- **Owner:** Sofia (customize DoD per mission)
- **Deadline:** Before implementation starts
- **Success metric:** DoD catches mission-specific requirements

**Action 4: Real-Time Blocker Notifications**
- **Problem:** Maya didn't know about 6h blocker
- **Action:** Developers notify Maya immediately when blocked >2h
  - Use Telegram: "@maya I'm blocked on [X], waiting for [Y]"
  - Maya updates client proactively (not reactively)
- **Owner:** All developers (new protocol)
- **Deadline:** Immediate (starts next mission)
- **Success metric:** Maya always knows blockers before client asks

---

**Part 6: Celebrate Wins (5 min)**

**Purpose:** End on positive note, recognize good work

**Sofia highlights:**
- "Kara deployed in one attempt. No rollback needed. Well done."
- "Reanance's AC.md was 100% complete. Zero ambiguity."
- "Bigbosexf caught all bugs before client saw them. Quality gate worked."
- "Maya's weekly status update impressed the client. They shared it internally."

**Team shout-outs:**
- Reanance to Rafael: "Code generation was 95% accurate. Made my job easy."
- Kara to Inna: "Deployment guide was perfect. No guessing."

### Meeting Structure (1 hour)

**Part 1: Week in Review (10 min) - Sofia presents**

**Wins:**
- ‚úÖ 3 missions delivered, 3 testimonials captured
- ‚úÖ Zero post-delivery bugs (perfect quality gate)
- ‚úÖ All clients satisfied (4.7/5 avg)

**Challenges:**

- ‚ö†Ô∏è Still some Rafael wait time (4.2h avg, down from 6h)
- ‚ö†Ô∏è Team at 75% utilization (could handle more, but timeline issues)

---

**Part 2: Pattern Recognition (15 min) - Group discussion**

**Facilitator asks:** "What patterns do you see across multiple missions?"

**Developer (Reanance):**
- "All 3 missions had same issue: spec phase smooth, implementation hits blockers."
- "Rafael code is always 90-95% complete, but edge cases need manual fixes."

**Developer (Kara):**
- "Deployment is smooth now (Inna's guides work). No deployment delays."
- "Most delays are in implementation phase, waiting for clarifications."

**QA (Bigbosexf):**
- "DoD customization is working. I caught mobile issues on Mission #47 because Sofia added it."
- "Bug count is consistent: 2-3 bugs per mission found in QA phase."

**Pattern identified:** Implementation phase consistently takes 30-50% longer than planned because of edge case handling and clarifications.

---

**Part 3: Root Cause Deep Dive (15 min)**

**Why are implementations 30-50% over planned timeline?**

**Hypothesis 1:** AC.md doesn't include enough implementation detail
- **Evidence:** Developers ask Reanance for clarifications during implementation
- **Test:** Review all 3 AC.md files. Do they have implementation guidance?

**Hypothesis 2:** Rafael's code gen doesn't handle edge cases
- **Evidence:** All 3 missions had edge case bugs found in QA
- **Test:** Compare Rafael's generated code to final implementation

**Hypothesis 3:** Developers spend time debugging instead of implementing
- **Evidence:** Git commits show 40% of time is bug fixing, not feature building
- **Test:** Review commit messages. How many are "fix bug" vs "add feature"?

**Discussion reveals:**
- AC.md has functional criteria (what) but not implementation hints (how)
- Rafael generates code based on AC.md, which lacks edge case specs
- Developers find edge cases during implementation, not during spec
- QA finds more edge cases, requiring rework

**Root cause:** Edge cases are discovered during implementation/QA instead of during spec phase. This causes rework and delays.

---

**Part 4: Team-Wide Improvements (15 min)**

**Improvement 1: Inna's MECHANISM Section Enhancement**
- **Problem:** AC.md lacks implementation hints
- **Action:** Inna adds "Common Edge Cases" subsection to MECHANISM
  - Invalid inputs (null, empty, wrong type)
  - Error conditions (API down, network timeout, rate limit)
  - Performance edge cases (large files, many records)
  - Security edge cases (injection, XSS, auth bypass)
- **Owner:** Inna (update template + all citizen CLAUDE.md references)
- **Deadline:** This week (before next mission)
- **Success metric:** Developers ask <2 clarifications per mission

**Improvement 2: Rafael Edge Case Test Generation**
- **Problem:** Rafael doesn't generate edge case tests
- **Action:** Rafael generates tests for edge cases in addition to happy path
  - Based on Inna's "Common Edge Cases" section
  - Generate Playwright/PyTest tests for each edge case
  - Developers run tests before claiming "implementation complete"
- **Owner:** Rafael (update code generation prompts)
- **Deadline:** This week
- **Success metric:** QA finds <2 bugs per mission (down from 2-3)

**Improvement 3: Timeline Estimation Adjustment**
- **Problem:** Implementation consistently 30-50% over planned
- **Action:** Alexis updates timeline estimates
  - Add 40% buffer to implementation phase
  - Communicate realistic timelines to clients upfront
  - Track actual vs estimated to refine over time
- **Owner:** Alexis (update pricing/timeline templates)
- **Deadline:** This week
- **Success metric:** 80% of missions delivered on-time next month

---

- **Reanance:** Edge case thinking (practice: "what could go wrong?" for each feature)
- **Kara:** Debugging efficiency (learning: use debugger, not console.log)
